BLACK AND WHITE PHOTO OF JESSE OWENS ON THE MEDAL STAND
FOOTAGE OF JEREMY BLOOM RACING THROUGH MOGULS, (FILE)
BLACK AND WHITE PHOTO OF MATTHEW ROBINSON AS AN OLD MAN
BLACK AND WHITE PHOTO OF A CATCHER TRYING TO PUT THE TAG
BLACK AND WHITE PHOTO OF MATTHEW ROBINSON CROSSING A FINI
HOME VIDEO OF THE FATHER HELPING A YOUNG BOY WITH HOMEWOR
BLACK AND WHITE PHOTO OF AN AFRICAN-AMERICAN MAN CIRCA 19

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we don’t know what we’re looking at yet. In front of is just a greyish-white flurry with nothing to orient us no sound except the whistle of a strong wind at a high altitude. We won’t know where we are until-- --a rocket flies right in front of us--right to left--and disappears from the frame as fast as it came into it. But probably saw it long enough to know it wasn’t a rocket, i was a world-class skier and we were standing five feet aw as she scorched the last few seconds of her run.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: A survey was taken a few years ago that asked 300 professionals one question:

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “What’s the worst thing that can happen in sports?” We're at the bottom of the slope now where the skier we j saw finished her run with a swoosh, and a hundred or so spectators gave her a round. The skier snapped out of her skis, picked them up, pushed up her goggles and looked ba up the slope toward the judges...

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Some people answered losing a Game 7 and other people said getting swept in 4. Some people said--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: --it was missing the World Cup and some Brazilians said it was losing to Argentina. Not just in the World Cup--anytime, ever, in any contest. We can see the whole slope now. It looks like a terrible to die. It’s a moguls course, meaning that skiers race through a punishing series of 3-foot mounds of packed sno and ice, lift-off and execute a mid-air trick, land and r through another set of moguls, lift-off and execute a sec trick, land and race to the finish. Spectators and race officials line the sides of the slope  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 2.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The skier we saw is looking back up the slope and now see her scores. Not bad, but not what she needed. She gets another round from the crowd and a less-than-wholehearted from her coach.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: But one person answered that the worst thing that can happen in sports was 4th-place at the Olympics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're at the top of the mountain where the next skiers ar waiting for their start. One of them has just jumped off mountain and into the course.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This is a true story but except for my own I’ve changed all the names and I’ve done my best to obscure identities for reasons that’1l become clear. I’m Molly Bloom and right now I’m ranked 3rd in North America in Women’s Moguls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The skier who just started has raced through the first se moguls, hits the ramp, which sends her up into mid-air wh she executes a trick and lands back on the course and hit the second set of moguls.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I have a BA in Political Science from the University of Colorado where I graduated Summa Cum Laude with a 3.9 GPA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The skier’s made her way through the second set of backbreaking moguls and hits the second ramp, which sends into the air. We watch the judges examine her trick with expert eyes and then tap the keys on their laptops.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I got a 173 on the L-SATs. The median L-SAT score at Harvard Law School is 169.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 3.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This one’s much friendlier and families are skiing togeth in the sun with the Rocky Mountains as a backdrop. A COAC working with a 12-YEAR-OLD BOY, showing him the right mechanics for his push-off.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I was raised in Loveland, Colorado, about an hour outside Denver or four hours if it’s snowing. On a weekend family ski trip when I was 5 I was spotted by a coach. The COACH stopped paying attention to the 12-YEAR-OLD BOY became captivated by the sight of a 5-YEAR-OLD GIRL--a prodigy--who’s just exploded into his field of vision. Th COACH watches and then glances back up the slope where th girl’s FATHER is standing and watching.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: (shouting) Attack it, Molly! Attack it! The COACH watches as the 5-YEAR-OLD GIRL hits the mini-mo section of the run.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I'd spend the next 18 years chasing winter and being coached by the best in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Runners are competing in a road race and the front of the pack comes toward us as well-wishers cheer and hand out c of water along the sides.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I also ran pretty well. A 12-YEAR OLD GIRL appears among the runners--both the fi kid and the first female we’ve seen. She’s running alongs her FATHER and you can tell just by looking at her stride that this is an athlete.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I was running in a charity 5K when my back exploded.

dialogues.speaker: 12-YEAR-OLD GIRL
dialogues.text: (to her FATHER) Something’s wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tough it out. The 12-YEAR-OLD GIRL gives her father a quick “thanks” gl that her father doesn’t see before she pulls out several strides ahead of him and the rest of the men around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The 12-YEAR OLD-GIRL is being prepped for surgery.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I had what’s called rapid onset scoliosis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An x-ray of a terribly curved spine.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My spine was curved at 63 degrees and I’d need a 7-hour surgical procedure that involved--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An x-ray of the same spine now fused with steel rods.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: --straightening my spine, extracting bone from my hip, fusing eleven vertebrae together and fastening steel rods to the fused segments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The 12-YEAR-OLD GIRL is in a hospital bed, post-op. From POV we can barely make out what a DOCTOR is saying to her FATHER and MOTHER.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: She’s gonna be fine, but I wouldn’t let her ski anymore. Definitely not moguls and skiing competitively is out of the question. The FATHER is quietly devastated and slumps down on the closest surface while the DOCTOR and the MOTHER assure hi that “...she’s gonna be fine, she just won’t ski”, etc. W stay on the 12-YEAR-OLD GIRL’s eyes--she’s clocked her father’s reaction and even through her post-op morphine h her eyes are fighting back.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 5.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I was on skis again in a year, running moguls in 18 months and by my 20th birthday I’d made the U.S. Ski Team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s the slope we started at. Number 87 is MOLLY.

dialogues.speaker: RACE OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: Number 87 up. (pointing) 56 on deck. takes her place at the starting gate and Number 56 She’s got earbuds in and a coach is vigorously rubbing down her legs to keep them warm.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It’s the last round of qualifying for the Salt Lake City Olympics. This is the Champion Run at Deer Valley. We can see that visibility is terrible, with snow coming diagonally and the wind whistling ominously at this altit

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The altitude’s 8100 feet and the pitch is 52 degrees which is the same as the sides of the Great Pyramids. MOLLY stomps on her feet to keep them warm and starts to loosen her shoulders and neck.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: The wind’s 20-25 miles an hour blowing left to right. It’s 3-below zero at the top of the slope and with 17 skiers in front of me, it’s gonna be like trying to stick a landing on a frozen infinity pool. The COACH points to his ears, indicating that it’s time f Molly to take out her ear buds. She hands the coach her i as he says--

dialogues.speaker: COACH
dialogues.text: Kiki blew out of her line. Shannon was off-balance on her second landing.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 6. MOLLY nods that she understands.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: He’s talking about Kiki Bandy and Shannon Keebler, my two toughest competitors who had significant point deductions on their final runs--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A skier landing slightly off-balance after a trick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another skier skiing out of her line and scrambling to recover.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: --setting the table for me. MOLLY snaps her boots into her bindings and taps her skis check how they feel.

dialogues.speaker: RACE OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: Number 56 up. 44 on deck.

dialogues.speaker: COACH
dialogues.text: Go get it, here we go. MOLLY snaps her goggles down as the Coach steps back. MOL all alone now at the top of the mountain, snow blowing ar her.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I can make the Olympic team right now. And if I have three perfect runs in Salt Lake--the best runs of my life--I can beat the Austrians and the Swiss and have a realistic shot at the podium. Then the law school of my choice and then a start-up. A foundation that seeds entrepreneurial women and also teaches young girls to ignore most of their current role models.

dialogues.speaker: RACE OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: Competitor ready.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: But first this.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 7. A small light, accompanied by beeps, blinks red, then yel then-- MOLLY jams her poles into the snow and launches herself o the slope.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Good start. My father’s at the bottom trying to telepathically get me to check my line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Molly’s FATHER is looking up the slope--

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Check your line.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I check my line. MOLLY’S POV Out of the sea of moguls she’s slashing through her eyes the path she’s chosen and, for a moment, it becomes demarcated for us like runway lights before it goes away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She’s carving through this minefield, kicking up snow and not being able to see more than ten feet in front of her

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Good snow contact, calm upper-body, * legs together, good shape, no line deviation and set up for the D-Spin * and-- * MOLLY sails into the air and executes a perfect back-flip with an off-axis twist.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: --stick the landing. Now two things you need to know before the second trick which’ll be a 720. As MOLLY attacks the next set of moguls we start to gradu SLOW DOWN THE PICTURE... (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 8.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The first is that when visibility * is bad the way it is now, race officials jam pine boughs in the snow at the edge of the jump so the skiers have some foreground depth reference. The second is that the * tightness of your bindings is determined by what’s called a DIN setting. If you’re a beginner your DIN setting is probably 2 or 3. If you’re an experienced weekend skier it’s probably 7 or 8. Mine’s 15. My boots are basically welded to my skis. Right...so how does this happen?-- In semi-slow motion, MOLLY gets airborne for her second t and almost as soon as she does, her right ski comes off a falls to the ground. All sound except Molly’s voice goes out.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It happened because I hit a pine bough and I hit it so precisely * that it simply snapped the release on my bindings. Right in that moment I didn’t have time to calculate the odds of that happening because I was about to land pretty hard on my digitally remastered spinal cord which is being held together by spare parts * from an Erector Set. MOLLY crashes to the ice and snow with terrible impact. * We go back to FULL SPEED now with Molly’s other ski immediately snapping off and skidding away as MOLLY keeps sliding and flipping over. We're still without sound--just the occasional slap of he helmet on the packed snow. And then her helmet flies off before she breaks through--MOS--the wood and wire fence a into a group of gasping and shouting spectators. We watch the whole thing again full speed. And we watch o watch it--SPECTATORS, her COACH, the JUDGES, TELEVISION C and her FATHER... Sound kicks back in and we hear the gasping crowd along w radio crackle of the SKI PATROL and EMTs as they race to scene. Molly’s FATHER tries to get to her as fast as he c MOLLY’s on her back, unconscious, blood-soaked snow on he face.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 9.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: None of this has anything to do with poker. I’m only mentioning it because I wanted to say to whoever answered that the worst thing that could happen in sports was 4th place at the Olympics--seriously, fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: Molly’s Game

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: INT. MOLLY’S APARTMENT/BEDROOM - NIGHT It’s a modest one-bedroom in West Hollywood and at the mo it’s all but unfurnished. She’s just moved in and has har any possessions. The CAMERA FINDS an open carton containing new copies of book--Molly’s Game: My High-Stakes Adventure in the World Underground Poker--with a glamour-shot of Molly on the gl cover. Leaning against the wall is a foam board blow-up o the book jacket with a banner across it announcing that y can meet Molly Bloom at a book signing. That’s pretty muc it.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: 12 Years Later West Hollywood

We come to MOLLY, asleep in her bed. She holds two Blackberries on her chest as she sleeps. It’s become an o habit. Suddenly we hear some kind of muffled commotion coming fr outside in the corridor and down the hall. It’s impossibl make out what’s being said--it’s all shouted whispers and confusion. MOLLY opens her eyes, thinking she’s heard something, but the commotion has gone away and there’s silence. Suddenly one of her Blackberries RINGS and it startles he moment. She answers--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (into the phone) Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy)

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE, (ON THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: Molly Bloom?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (into the phone) Yes?

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE, (ON THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: Is this Molly Bloom?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (into the phone) Yes, who is this?

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE, (ON THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: Miss Bloom, this is Special Agent Delarosa of the FBI and we have a warrant for your arrest. We’re outside your door and we want you to come out here. Listen to me now. Make sure we can see your hands.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (pause--then into the phone) Who is this?

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE, (ON THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: Molly, you've got 30 seconds to come to your door or we’re breaking it down. Do you understand what I just said?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE, (ON THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: Say you understand.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I understand.

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE, (ON THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: Come to the door now. Make sure we can see your hands at all times. dressed in a t-shirt and boxer shorts, front door. She still has her athlete’s body, plenty scared, She opens the door and steps into-- 10. goes to her and while she’s we can still detect steel behind her eyes.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 11.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Molly’s apartment is at one end of a long hallway and at other end are 17 blinding flashlights attached to 17 automatic weapons which are trained on her.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT DELAROSA
dialogues.text: Hands in the air. Molly Bloom?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: There’s been a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT DELAROSA
dialogues.text: Are you Molly Bloom?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT DELAROSA
dialogues.text: I want you to walk toward me very slowly. Go ahead, come on. MOLLY’s walking toward the crowd of flashlights... AGENT DELAROSA (CONT’D) Slower, slow down.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT DELAROSA
dialogues.text: Slower.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I can’t see. The flashlights--

dialogues.speaker: AGENT DELAROSA
dialogues.text: Walk slower.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I think there’s been a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT DELAROSA
dialogues.text: Are you Molly Bloom?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yes sir. A FEMALE AGENT takes hold of MOLLY and puts her up agains the wall.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE AGENT
dialogues.text: Spread your arms and legs please. While the FEMALE AGENT pats her down--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 12.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT DELAROSA
dialogues.text: Is there anyone in your apartment right now?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: No sir.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT DELAROSA
dialogues.text: Are there any firearms in your apartment right now?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: No sir. AGENT DELAROSA turns to the other AGENTS--

dialogues.speaker: AGENT DELAROSA
dialogues.text: Go. The agents head down the hallway and go into the apartmen one by one, just like they were taught at the Academy, stopping at the door and then turning in quickly--all thi handcuffs go on Molly. AGENT DELAROSA (CONT’D) You’re under arrest for running an illegal gambling operation, do you understand?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT DELAROSA
dialogues.text: Say you understand.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I understand. I think there’s been a mistake because I haven’t run a game in two years.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT DELAROSA
dialogues.text: I want you to look at this piece of paper, do you see what it says at the top?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (pause) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT DELAROSA
dialogues.text: Read to me what it says at the top.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: The United States of America vs. Molly Bloom.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 13. In the background, agents start coming back out into the saying, “Clear,” “It’s clear,” etc.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'd bet heavy on the favorite.

dialogues.speaker: A 13-YEAR-OLD GIRL
dialogues.text: She’s the same girl we saw running in the 5K and she’s be taped on a CAMCORDER. There’s something about this girl. She’s uncomfortably sexy for her age--a father’s nightmar but she’s also oddly mature and very serious. Off screen FATHER is asking her questions. She answers simply and evenly.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What do you think about the following concepts? I’m just gonna run them by you. Marriage.

dialogues.speaker: 13-YEAR-OLD GIRL
dialogues.text: Hm. It is a trap.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Society.

dialogues.speaker: 13-YEAR-OLD GIRL
dialogues.text: It is a joke.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: People.

dialogues.speaker: 13-YEAR-OLD GIRL
dialogues.text: I think there’s good and bad. I think there's jealousy. A lot of people are out to get you. I don’t trust them. I don’t trust people. The frame freezes with the GIRL’s eyes looking off-screen her father.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Every year on our birthdays my father would interview my younger brothers and me.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Who are the heroes or heroines in your life? Who do you really respect?  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 14.

dialogues.speaker: 13-YEAR-OLD GIRL
dialogues.text: I don’t have any heroes.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You don’t have any heroes.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: How's this for hubris? *

dialogues.speaker: 13-YEAR-OLD GIRL
dialogues.text: I don’t. Because if I reach the goals I set out for myself, then the person I become, that’1ll be my hero. Because there’s no one I can look at right now who's accomplished what I want to accomplish. Again the frame freezes with the girl’s eyes looking off- screen, almost accusingly, at her father. *

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Even by teenage girl standards I would appear to be irrationally angry at nothing in particular. It would be another 7 years before I'd find out why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights of Los Angeles begin to shimmer into view thro the windshield of a Jeep Grand Cherokee.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: After my wipeout at Deer Valley I decided to take a year off before law school. Law school’s hard and I couldn’t spend the first year thinking about a pine bough. I needed to go away, sever myself from reality and come up with a new * plan so I chose Los Angeles, a city * whose entire population has severed itself from reality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOLLY pulls her lone duffle bag out of the Jeep, throws t strap over her shoulder, walks to the front door and ring the bell.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Blair, a friend of mine from the ski team, had agreed to let me crash on her couch for a while. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 15.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My father had disapproved of postponing law school and so declined to help out, but I had seventeen-hundred dollars I'd saved in baby sitting money and that would support me until I found a waitressing job. BLAIR’s opened the front door. Blair’s pretty but it’s th middle of the night--closer to dawn--and she’s been party The two hug. INT. BLAIR’S HOUSE/LIVING ROOM - A FEW MINUTES LATER MOLLY finishes making up the couch.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I'd already had a career and retired from it. I wanted to be young for a while in warm weather. BLAIR says good night and switches off the lights in the living room. MOLLY sits on the couch alone.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (beat) I think that’s what I wanted at first. It’s hard to remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long line outside a velvet rope with a bouncer tells us this club is hard to get into.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I got a job working bottle service at a club in Hollywood called Nacional. It was Cuban-themed so my uniform was camouflage short-shorts and a white wife-beater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We take a tour through the club, which is packed and thum with music.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 16.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: The promoter would go over which record producer was sitting where-- which hot designers, which Lakers and Jolo the Malaysian billionaire who didn’t drink but who ran a hundred-thousand dollar bar tab. My job was to get people to spend much more money than they needed to. MOLLY’s attending to a table--

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: We'll have a bottle of Sky.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You guys look like you deserve Grey Goose.

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: What do guys who look like they deserve Grey Goose look like?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: They have a bottle of Grey Goose in front of them.

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: Quick. Clever. I like that. As MOLLY finishes at the table and heads back to the bar-

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: They just spent an additional three- hundred dollars, bringing their total to nine-hundred dollars for eight dollars and fifty-cents worth of vodka. MOLLY passes some sexy young women who are hanging out at

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: But the club doesn’t need you to buy a bottle, they need you to buy five bottles. So these girls over here, they let you buy them shots for a living. It would be like waiting in a long line to get into the Gap so you can pay a one- thousand percent mark-up to buy all the employees a pair of pants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 17.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s one of those two-story buildings on the west end of Sunset Strip. It’s not a dive but it doesn’t scream first class. MOLLY’s Grand Cherokee pulls into a space next to a silve Mercedes AMG. MOLLY gets out, dressed for her first day o work in an office.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I only had one shift a week, I * didn’t want to tell my parents I was a cocktail waitress and back * then I never turned down an * opportunity to make more money so I found a second job as an office assistant and that’s how I ended up working for Reardon Greene. Reardon was a partner in Bluerock Investments. He was a regular at the club and one night he said--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REARDON is at a table drinking with some friends and some girls. He’s in his late 30’s, not very tall, hair slicked back, 3-day beard, skull and cross-bones t-shirt and he’s talking to MOLLY-- *

dialogues.speaker: REARDON
dialogues.text: Well how’d you like to get paid to * go to grad school and get a fuckin’ * MBA in how life works?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: What makes you think you know and I don't?

dialogues.speaker: REARDON
dialogues.text: I’m a customer here and you're a waitress here, look at the scoreboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s three offices and a reception area.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 18.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I can’t tell you what my job was. I’m not saying it’s a secret, I literally can’t tell you what my job was. So I made it up. MOLLY’s sat down in front of an empty desk and regarded i for a moment. What is she supposed to do? She picks up th phone and checks for a dial tone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She files papers.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I filed contracts using a system I borrowed from the alphabet, with “B" following “A” and so forth.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I answered the phone, made coffee runs, set appointments, made spreadsheets and showed Reardon what spreadsheets were. MOLLY’s pointing at her computer screen and explaining ho spreadsheet works to REARDON, dressed in his usual fatigu and skull t-shirt and looking at a copy of LA X-Press. He puts the paper down next to Molly and tells her--MOS--whi girl he likes.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And ordered call girls. INT. BLAIR’S HOUSE - EARLY MORNING MOLLY’s asleep on the couch and we can see through the wi that it’s still mostly dark outside.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: But I made four-hundred and fifty dollars a week on top of the three hundred I was making at the club, which would be enough to get off * Blair’s couch. * Her cell phone rings. She opens her eyes and reaches for phone.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 19.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I remember the day started by being about bagels.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (into phone) This is (Molly).

dialogues.speaker: REARDON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (over) Get to the office. Pick up bagels.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Do you mean now? (pause) Hello? Reardon’s hung up. MOLLY hits a button on the phone to ch the time--5:25AM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOLLY comes out of the store with a bag of bagels.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Reardon was a Hollywood staple. Over-leveraged, into the company assets, going broke trying to prove he wasn’t broke and making a true effort to be as vulgar as possible. Honestly making an effort. She’s gotten into her jeep and her phone Buzzes with a te from Reardon-- “Move your fuckin’ ass” She tosses the phone aside and pulls the car out onto Sun which is nearly empty because of the hour, but we can see that LA’s decorated for Christmas. INT. REARDON’S OFFICE - NIGHT REARDON is hammering home a deal to three INVESTORS, tell them they'd be fuckin’ idiots not to put money into this. MOLLY’s sitting and taking notes on her laptop.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: But somehow he was making hundred- million dollar deals every day and I got to watch him do it. “Bizness Biznessa”, as they say in the Ukraine. The business of business. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 20.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And I was surprised to learn I liked it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOLLY’s hustling up a flight of stairs with the bag of ba

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I hadn’t told anyone that I was a skier and it was hard not to laugh when Reardon said-- She opens the door at the top of the stairs and walks int

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REARDON is standing there-- *

dialogues.speaker: REARDON
dialogues.text: Did anyone ever teach you how to fuckin’ hurry?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: REARDON
dialogues.text: What are those?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Bagels. REARDON snatches the bag from MOLLY-- *

dialogues.speaker: REARDON
dialogues.text: Are these from Pink Dot?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: It’s on the way from (my house).

dialogues.speaker: REARDON
dialogues.text: Seriously? You might as well have stopped at a fuckin’ homeless shelter! You might as well have walked into a motherfucking homeless shelter and said, “I'd like a dozen bagels from this homeless shelter please!” I do not eat bagels from Pink fucking Dot, Molly, these are fucking poor people bagels!  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 21. REARDON throws the bag at MOLLY’s head and MOLLY easily t out of the way of the throw.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: From where would you like me to get your bagels in the future?

dialogues.speaker: REARDON
dialogues.text: Forget about the fuckin’ bagels.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Done.

dialogues.speaker: REARDON
dialogues.text: Except smarten up.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Got it.

dialogues.speaker: REARDON
dialogues.text: Hang on. REARDON disappears into his office for a second-- *

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Like I said, the day started by being about bagels but that would abruptly change. REARDON comes back out with a legal pad that he’s writing as he scrolls through his phone to find numbers.--

dialogues.speaker: REARDON
dialogues.text: (still writing) We’re doing a poker game at the Viper Room. Tomorrow night and then every Tuesday night. You’ll help run it. Take these names and numbers and invite them. Tell ‘em to bring ten grand in cash for the first buy-in, the blinds are fifty/one-hundred. REARDON drops the pad on Molly’s desk. MOLLY stares at th pad... REARDON (CONT’D) And Molly?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: REARDON
dialogues.text: Don’t fucking tell anybody. REARDON disappears into his office. *  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 22.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I'd regarded Reardon as a nitwit when I regarded him at all, but on that pad were nine names--along with phone numbers--of some of the wealthiest and most influential people in Los Angeles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOLLY’s typing away on her Blackberry--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I put the numbers in my phone and composed a simple message-- Molly hits send. Then puts her phone down on the desk and Googles “poker/blinds”.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: --that there’d be a game tomorrow night at the Viper Room, there was a ten-thousand dollar buy-in and the blinds were fifty anda hundred. Molly begins reading about blinds when all of a sudden he phone starts buzzing with text after text--”I’m in,” “I’l there,” “Yes,” “I’m in”... MOLLY turns her head and looks at her phone blowing up wi responses.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: All nine players confirmed that they'd be there. Within 90 seconds of my sending the text.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We establish the front of the iconic club before circling around to the back where the Jeep is parked and MOLLY’s pulling out a carton of liquor bottles and a cheese platt

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: The Viper Room was owned by Bugsy Siegel in the 40’s back when it was called the Melody Room and before his childhood friend Meyer Lansky had him shot 43 times in the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ee  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As MOLLY makes her way through the dark and seedy hallway balancing the cheese platter on the carton of bottles.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: All I knew was schoolwork and skiing. I’d always figured sophistication would be easy to learn if I ever needed it. My cheese platter had a sticker that said, “Cheese: From the Great State of Michigan.” She goes into--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I'd Googled, “What type of music do poker players like to listen to?” and then tried to figure out how to make a playlist out of one Kenny Rogers song. She arrives at--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --where DIEGO has kicked out the legs of an oval card tab and sets it upright with a slam.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Diego, a professional dealer, was setting up the table when I got there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room and the table are set up for the game and now we hear the thumping music coming from upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I set up the bar, put out my cheese platter and positioned myself at the door where I’d been instructed to only let in the names on the list, which I'd memorized. I was wearing my best dress, which I'd bought two years earlier at JC Penny for 88-dollars. MOLLY stands waiting at the doorway and adjusts herself slightly.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 24.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: The players started to arrive. I introduced myself as Molly, Reardon’s assistant, asked if I could get them a drink and took from each of them ten-thousand dollars in cash. Through a SERIES OF DISSOLVES --we'll see the PLAYERS arriving, chatting a moment with MOLLY--some of them flirting a little and others being ma of fact--and handing her envelopes. We’ll pay special attention to one player in particular who we’ll get to kn in a moment--we call him PLAYER X. The final DISSOLVE is Reardon showing up--

dialogues.speaker: REARDON
dialogues.text: Everybody here?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: REARDON
dialogues.text: Ugly dress. Ugly shoes. (calling out) Let’s play!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIEGO the dealer fans 9 cards out on the table and the players each start picking a card--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Diego fanned 9 cards out on the table and the players chose for seats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A stack of chips gets slapped on the table as an opening and ina --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --we see cards being dealt, bets being raised, hands bein folded, Molly making a vodka and Red Bull, the final card being flipped, hands, chips, cards, vodka and Red Bull et  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 25. MOLLY’s in the corner. She’s standing at a small table with her laptop open, watching, listening and Googling. We pus on her slowly, cutting in the action of the game as we go all the while hearing the thumping of the music from upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I'd just finished counting out ninety-thousand dollars in cash. I was in a room with movie stars, directors, rappers, boxers and business titans. They were going all-in all the time, burning through their buy-ins over and over. REARDON’s come over to Molly--

dialogues.speaker: REARDON
dialogues.text: You're keeping track of the buy- ins?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: REARDON
dialogues.text: Where? Where’s the paper?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (pointing to the laptop) Spreadsheet. REARDON takes a moment and then nods his approval before go back to another

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More chips fly in, drinks are put down, cards are flipped players jump up in victory and pound the table in defeat, throw their cards at Diego, the seal on a new deck gets c more buy-ins, more drinks, more chips, more cards and the thump thump thump of the music from upstairs...MOLLY’s ty at her laptop.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I Googled every word I heard that I didn’t know. Flop, river, fourth street, tilt, cooler, boat, nuts, playing the rush, cold deck--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The game is over and the room is clearing out--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 26.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: The game ended at 2:30. And when it did, that’s when Reardon shouted out--

dialogues.speaker: REARDON
dialogues.text: (calling out) Hey! Tip Molly if you want to get invited back next week. As players leave they say goodbye to MOLLY, some of them giving her a kiss on the cheek while they hand her some c or some cash.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Tip Molly. Deep down I didn’t like the sound of that. Deep down I knew that when your boss says--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --where Reardon says--

dialogues.speaker: REARDON
dialogues.text: And Molly?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: REARDON
dialogues.text: Don’t fuckin’ tell anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOLLY’s alone counting out hundreds--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: --that’s usually not the beginning of a promising law career. But that was deep down. I'd just made three- thousand dollars. MOLLY stares at the cash in her hands and smiles...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 27.

dialogues.speaker: MORNING JOE
dialogues.text: MOLLY’s a guest on the show and her book cover--Molly’s G is projected in back of them.

dialogues.speaker: MIKA BRZEZINSKI
dialogues.text: What’s the most you ever went home with?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: In one night?

dialogues.speaker: MIKA BRZEZINSKI
dialogues.text: In one night.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: A hundred and fifty-thousand dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s present day and these are the offices of a high-end, prestigious law firm. It’s early in the morning and the p is completely empty except for MOLLY, who’s sitting and waiting in her best professional clothes. She’s mentally physically exhausted but keeps it to herself. The morning newspapers are fanned out on the coffee table in the bottom right corner of The New York Post is a box a picture of Molly and a small headline that reads: “Poke Princess Arraigned Today”. MOLLY casually takes one of th other papers and slides it over her photo. Also sitting and waiting is a 14-year-old girl--STELLA--w dressed in a private school uniform and reading a copy of Crucible. STELLA’s the opposite of precocious. After a long moment of silence...

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (pause) What are you reading?

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: The Crucible.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: For school?

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: (shakes her head no) My father assigned it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 28. MOLLY nods and there’s another long silence...

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (pause) You know how many witches were burned in Salem?

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: No. It doesn’t say.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: None. They didn’t burn witches in Salem, it’s a myth, that’s not how they killed them.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: How did they kill them?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: They hanged them or drowned them. Sometimes they piled heavy stones on their chests until they crushed them.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: You're Molly Bloom, right?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: You don’t look like you do in the pictures.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: None of us do. We hear the clacking of footsteps coming down the hall an CHARLIE JAFFEY comes into view. CHARLIE’s a nice-looking with a kind face--around the same age as Molly or a coupl years older. He’s dressed well but not flashy.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Molly?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I’m Charlie Jaffey.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Thank you again for seeing me.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You've met my daughter Stella?  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 29.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (to Stella) Isabel’s gonna be here in 45 minutes to take you to school. Did you finish the math?

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Civ?

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Do you know it? Could you teach it to your class today? If I asked you about Roman law, could you tell me?

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: ‘Kay, keep reading. MOLLY clocked that. CHARLIE (CONT’D) (to Molly) There aren’t too many people here this early but we’ll have coffee soon. Come on back to my office. MOLLY follows CHARLIE down a hallway-- CHARLIE (CONT’D) First thing’s first, when was the last time you slept? (beat) Today’s Friday.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Tuesday morning at 5AM I was arrested by the FBI. I spent Tuesday at LA County Jail. I was assessed to be a minimal flight risk and my bail was set ata hundred-thousand dollars. My mother signed over her house. I was released Wednesday morning and ordered to appear in Federal Court in New York’s Southern District at 10AM today.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 30.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: In here. They walk into-- INT. CHARLIE’S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS It’s a beautiful corner office with jetliner views of the river.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I flew here Wednesday and met with five attorneys yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you hire any of them?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Three of them had already been taken.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, there were 31 people named in your indictment--it’s Black Friday for criminal lawyers. What about the other two?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: One told me that money was his second favorite form of payment.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: And the fifth was also taken but he recommended I call you.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I told him I wanted someone who'd worked in the prosecutor’s office. That didn’t narrow the field much but then I told him I needed someone who wasn’t even a little bit shady because I’ve had some experience with that and that’s when the list got short. I told him I needed someone very good because this is nuanced. And I was given one day to find an attorney. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy)

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (pause) Do you know about me?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (pause) I've been briefed a little by my daughter who knows a lot about your story because her mother’s a moron.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: The tabloids.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I’ve read some of the tabloids and I read the indictment after I got your call last night and I bought your book. CHARLIE’s picked up a copy of Molly’s Game-- CHARLIE (CONT’D) I’m only up to page 81, but Molly? Did you commit a felony and then publish a memoir about it?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I haven’t run a game in over two years. Not to spoil the ending but that’s when the government raided my game and took all my money, assuming all of it was made illegally which it wasn’t. I’ve been living at my mother’s house in Keystone and I wrote the book so I could start paying debts. I just finished a press tour for the book and moved back to Los Angeles.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Just to nail down the timeline, you ran games in LA for roughly six years?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Without taking a rake.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Then you ran games in New York for roughly two years? 31.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 32.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I took a rake the last six months.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Then your game got raided, the government took all your money ina civil forfeiture and you left town.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I went to live with my mother at her house in Colorado. That was two years ago.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: And it was there that you wrote this book.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: The book was released three weeks ago, you did a press tour and moved back to LA.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: And that’s where you were arrested by the FBI.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (pause) So...In the first 81 pages you name a bunch of names.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (beat) I’m sorry?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You gave up the names of some movie stars who played in your game. MOLLY takes a moment...this is obviously a sore spot for and she’d rather not talk about it.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (pause) Yeah.  33.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Isn’t that against some sort of poker code?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: There’s no poker code and there’s no law against lack of discretion.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Wouldn’t it be great if there were, though?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Are you taking me on as a client?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: My retainer’s $250,000, do you have

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: No, I don’t have anything.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What about sales of the book?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Including that one that you bought I’ve sold one copy, but there's a lot of interest from Hollywood in buying my life rights. I’ll find a way to pay you. Charlie, ask around about me, my word is good.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Not to the guys you named.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I didn’t have a--just ask around about me.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (laughing) Unfortunately the people I'd ask are goin’ away for a while. What happened Tuesday morning was called a GPS Takedown. 31 people were arrested in the same instant. Someone you thought was a friend called you on your phone to make sure it was the one you were still using and when you answered that call, they had you painted and kept track of your movements until the agreed upon time. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 34.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Something in excess of 600 agents were dispatched to locations in New York and LA in coordinated strikes with automatic weapons and you’re trying to tell me you’re in my office because you raked a game of Texas Hold ‘Em?!

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Have you seen the other names on this indictment? Helly Habib, Mike Druzhinsky, Mike Anikovich, the Gershen Brothers? How deep were you into the Russian mob, Molly?! ‘Cause so far your tell-all doesn’t say. MOLLY’s well past tired and Charlie’s quick cross-examina has either taken something out of her or put something ba in. She stands up and walks to the window...

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (pause) Why are you making your daughter read The Crucible?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: So she can see what happens when a group of bored teenage girls gossip.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I’ve never read the play.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Many consider it to be the best play of the 20th Century.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Is that what many consider it to be?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I don’t defend violent criminals.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I’ve never hurt anyone in my life.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Your friends have.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 35.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I’ve never heard of 90 percent of the names in the indictment.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: And the other 10 percent?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I didn’t know they were mobsters, I had no idea who they really were.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (pause) Let me ask you something. Reardon-- in the book--he didn’t say “Poor people bagels,” did he. (beat) I think I know who he is, I think I know a real estate lawyer who worked with him and quit. He called them “nigger bagels,” right?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (pause) I’m not telling you his name, he’s not involved in this.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: But you were willing to name the movie stars.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: None of that matters. Why is the FBI arresting me two years after--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Were you paid extra in your book deal to name the movie stars?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (pause) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I’m not your guy, Molly. I wish you good luck but this just isn’t for me. MOLLY hears that but still doesn’t leave...

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (pause) Why did you leave the prosecutor's office and become a defense attorney?  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 36.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: My daughter.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You needed to make money.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: That and I was usually one of the few people who knew where witnesses were being hidden.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: It was dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Mm-hm. *

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: So you didn’t leave the * prosecutor’s office because you * wanted to stand up for the innocent and believe everyone’s entitled to the best defense?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Not really.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: It would have been helpful if you were Spencer Tracy or--I didn’t know who the Russians were. (pause--calmer) I can get you the two-hundred and fifty-thousand, I left ten times that on the street, it’ll just take some time. ee OF

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: We do pro bono work--we regularly lend out our best litigators like me to the ACLU, Southern Poverty Law Center, veterans groups--but I * don’t think I can convince my partners to take a flyer on the Poker Princess.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I didn’t name myself the Poker Princess. CHARLIE picks up a copy of Us Weekly that’s been tabbed a reads--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: “Molly Bloom, the self-proclaimed Poker Princess...”. *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 37.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: That's Us Weekly? I agree it would be unusual for them to print something that wasn’t true but it’s not true and if you think a princess could do what I did you’re incorrect. I’m getting that you don’t think much of me but what if every one of your ill-informed, unsophisticated opinions about me were wrong?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I'd be amazed.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yeah you know what, bud? You would.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You don’t need me, you need a publicist.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: No, I need a fuckin’ lawyer!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (pause) You never answered my question. When was the last time you slept?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (pause) It was a while ago.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (pause) I’m gonna walk you through the arraignment this morning, you shouldn’t do that alone. I’m gonna put some bodies on you and walk you through a side door. ‘Cause I don’t know what you’ve got on the Russians but neither do they and the Russians take care of shit, you understand what I’m saying?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SEVEN-YEAR-OLD GIRL is being pulled by a motor boat as tries to get up on one ski. She fails and falls hard into water.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 38. Her FATHER--the same father we’ve been seeing throughout- her MOTHER are on the boat and her FATHER shouts back--

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Again! The SEVEN-YEAR OLD GIRL is tired but she gets herself rea to try again. The MOTHER isn’t happy about this but seems helpless and slightly cowed by the force of the FATHER.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: My father’s a therapist and a psychology professor at Colorado State. The second rule of his house was that academic excellence and athletic excellence weren't optional and the first rule was that he made the rules. The GIRL is back on her water ski. The boat powers forwar again and the GIRL gets up on one ski for a moment before falls. The MOTHER, standing in the back of the boat as a spotter, raises a flag in the air to let nearby boats kno there’s a skier in the water.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: You’re not getting out of the water till you do this. Again!

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I was a skinny kid, and at 7 years old I didn’t have the core strength yet to pull this off. In October the water in Colorado is pretty cold and we'd been at this since 6AM.

dialogues.speaker: SEVEN-YEAR-OLD GIRL
dialogues.text: (calling) Dad? I’m tired. The FATHER shakes his head...the MOTHER looks down, feeli for her daughter but not wanting to start a fight.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: She’s tired. The FATHER whips the boat around and drives it up to the GIRL.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: You're tired?

dialogues.speaker: SEVEN-YEAR-OLD GIRL
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 39.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: What’s another word for tired? Name a synonym for tired and I’ll let you in the boat.

dialogues.speaker: SEVEN-YEAR-OLD GIRL
dialogues.text: (pause) Weak.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: That’s right. (holding out his hand) Get on in. The GIRL looks at her FATHER and his outstretched hand bu stays in the water...

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Again.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. BARNEY’S/SHOE DEPARTMENT - DAY MOLLY’s wearing cut-offs, a sweatshirt and a Denver Bronc baseball cap as she looks at herself in a pair of Christi Loubitans.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I’ll take them.

dialogues.speaker: SHOE SALESMAN
dialogues.text: Excellent.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Can you tell me what floor the dresses are on? INT. BARNEY’S/DRESS DEPARTMENT - A FEW MINUTES LATER

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: After three months of games I had enough money to buy some real clothes. A SALESWOMAN comes up to her--

dialogues.speaker: SALESWOMAN
dialogues.text: Can I pull some styles for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy)

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I’m looking for a dress that makes me look nothing like myself. The SALESWOMAN smiles...

dialogues.speaker: SALESWOMAN
dialogues.text: Take off your hat, put your hair in a bun and put on your new shoes. I’1l pull some options. INT. BARNEY’S - A FEW MINUTES LATER 40. MOLLY comes out of the dressing room wearing a black dres that makes her look very sexy...

dialogues.speaker: SALESWOMAN
dialogues.text: Well...where did that body come from? MOLLY stares at herself in the mirror...

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I decided to postpone law school another year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A game is underway and MOLLY has a whole new look.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I'd overheard stories about games that folded after one bad night and I needed this one to keep going and I needed to bring value to it. I knew if I wanted to cement my place there was one guy I needed to team up with and that was this man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a HAND LIFTING CARDS, FINGERS PLAYING WITH CHIPS a then see that they belong to PLAYER xX.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: The game had regulars and the game had guests and four of the regulars were famous actors and I’m going to call one of them Player X. Player xX subscribed to the belief that money won was twice as good as money earned. He lived to beat people and take their money. Here’s Player X talking one of the guests into folding the winning hand.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 4l. PLAYER X is in a showdown with the GUEST, who’s sweating whether to call or fold. The GUEST The GUEST

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER X
dialogues.text: I swear on my--look at me--I swear on my mother’s life--I have you.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Player X was the best player at the table and tonight this guy was the worst. He’s staring at his cards-- even a reasonably good amateur would know it was mathematically the best hand, which in poker is called the nuts. There was forty- seven thousand dollars in the pot and the guest was holding the nuts but he was starting to get confused because a movie star was talking to him.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER X
dialogues.text: My mother’s life man, I’m not messing with you. thinks...surveys the cards...

dialogues.speaker: GUEST
dialogues.text: (pause) Why would you be telling me?

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER X
dialogues.text: Either I am messing with you OR you’re new to the game, you’ve had bad cards all night, you should’ve folded after the flop and I don’t want to win more of your money this way. I’ve got queens under here. Take your time. takes another moment...then tosses in his cards.

dialogues.speaker: GUEST
dialogues.text: Fold. PLAYER X picks up his two losing hole cards--neither a qu and shows them to the guest--

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER X
dialogues.text: Fuck you! The others cheer and pound the table as PLAYER X hauls in chips and the guest tries to put on a “just one of the gu face.”  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 42.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: A fish is a particular kind of player. A fish has money. A fish plays loose and doesn’t fold a lot. A fish is good but not too good. PLAYER X looks over to MOLLY...MOLLY looks back and gives a half-smile. Chips get put down as a new hand is dealt.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: The Viper Room may have belonged to Reardon but the game belonged to Player X. People wanted to say they played with him the same way they wanted to say they rode on Air Force One. My job security was gonna depend on bringing him his fish. But where would I find people with a lot of money who didn’t know how to spend it and liked to be around celebrities?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The club where Molly used to work. MOLLY’s talking to fou the CLUB GIRLS who drink shots for a living as the place pulses around them.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: If they say they’re interested in poker you give them my number. I vet them. If they end up playing in the game I’ll give you a thousand dollars the first time they play and five-hundred every time after that. (handing one of them a slip of paper) Be sure to mention that these guys are all regulars. One of the club girls looks at the list of names...

dialogues.speaker: CLUB GIRL
dialogues.text: Is this true? MOLLY hands her a wad of cash as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 43.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s a sad, seedy casino and we’re in an area where an eclectic collection of guys are playing Texas Hold ‘Em. MOLLY’s standing near a pit boss and watching one of the players. ee OK

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: The Commerce Casino is off the 5 freeway in East LA and no one’s ever going to confuse it with the French Riviera. I’d watch the tables for a while before I approached a friendly-looking pit boss.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: The third chair at Table 8 can’t lose.

dialogues.speaker: PIT BOSS
dialogues.text: Unless there are players at his table who can win.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You know about the game at the Viper Room, right? *

dialogues.speaker: PIT BOSS
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: It’s a 10K buy-in, blinds are fifty and a hundred. A thousand for every player you send me. You get a piece of what they lose. No pros. I’m Molly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIEGO cuts the seal on a new deck and shuffles. *

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Poker was my Trojan horse into the highest levels of finance, technology, politics, art, entertainment--all I had to do was listen. SERIES OF SHOTS--Different games on different nights as M listens to conversations between players and Googles vari things she hears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy)

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER
dialogues.text: The art world is controlled by a few major dealers. Gagosian, Zwirner, and a couple more.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER
dialogues.text: China’s telecom companies want to partner with other providers.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER
dialogues.text: They alone control the market. They choose the artists they want to be important.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER
dialogues.text: Obama’s gonna run.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER
dialogues.text: They set the prices, they mark ‘em up 70, 80, 90 percent.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER
dialogues.text: The owners don’t mind paying thirty- million dollars to an outfielder who hits 320 with 110 RBI’s, they mind paying ten-million dollars for a pitcher who was 8 and 14 last season.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER
dialogues.text: 90 percent mark-up. It’s unregulated money, usually all cash and unreported.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER
dialogues.text: He’s the head of Google ventures and he says they’re working on a secret project to live forever.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER
dialogues.text: To do what?

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER
dialogues.text: Live forever.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER
dialogues.text: Are they close?

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER
dialogues.text: No. Call and raise.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER
dialogues.text: His days are numbered.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER
dialogues.text: His days are numbered.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER
dialogues.text: I don’t know how much longer she’s gonna be in that job.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER
dialogues.text: They’re very excited about a company called Twitter.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER
dialogues.text: He’s done.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER
dialogues.text: She’s gone.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER
dialogues.text: I’m all in.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: People have asked me what my goal was at that point, what was my endgame. Back then I would have laughed at that question. I was raised to be a champion, my goal was to win. At what and against whom? Those were just details.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 46. We’re on MOLLY’s face as a player, off-screen, says what Molly’s thinking...

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER
dialogues.text: All in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOLLY looks over the modest but nice new place with a ren agent.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I had my own apartment now--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOLLY gets out of a brand new Audi with a bag of bagels--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: --a new car and seventeen-thousand dollars in a shoebox.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOLLY’s standing alone in a crowd drinking a glass of * champagne.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: One night a friend asked me to come with her to a pre-Oscar party being hosted by the head of one of the bigger talent agencies. Nothing’1l remind you that you don’t belong * quite as fast as a party where you don’t belong. And I must’ve been invisible because two four-thousand dollar suits were talking business right next to me.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: He’s never gonna agree to that number.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: He’s already agreed to it. *

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: You know that? *

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: Rich played cards with him.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 47.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: Tuesday night at the game. *

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: The Lakers game? *

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: Cards. Poker. The poker game. *

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: I don’t know what you’re talking * about. *

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: Oh, man, you have to know about the * game. It’s exclusive, you need an * invitation, the winners are coming * home with a hundred thousand dollars and the losers keep coming back.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: Where do they play?

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: No one knows where. Nobody who plays talks about it and everybody wants in. But my point is that Rich played with him and he’s agreeing to the number.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And just like that, I was about to belong.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: I need to get a seat at this game. * MOLLY downs what’s left of her champagne and steps to the agents--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Excuse me, I couldn’t help overhearing you. (beat) I’m Molly Bloom and I run the game you were talking about. If you give me your cards I can get in touch if a seat opens.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: (pause) Seriously?  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 48.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: The game’s real?

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: Who plays?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You can just give me your cards. * They hand her their cards.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll be in touch. MOLLY walks away and we stay on her face as she glides * through the party and we see a small smile as we --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Press and paparazzi are on the steps behind police barricades. No one notices a black SUV has driven past th and pulls up to the side of the courthouse. A BODYGUARD hops out the front passenger side and opens t back door for another BODYGUARD who helps Molly out of th car. The three of them head for a side entrance as we --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE is standing and waiting as MOLLY and the bodyguar come in and walk through a metal detector. They all make their way down the hall--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Here’s all that’s gonna happen today. The judge is gonna ask each defendant if they’ve read the indictment or if they’d like the court to read it to them. Then the judge is going to ask you how you plead and you’ll answer, “Not Guilty.” I’ll make it clear for the record that I’m not your counsel but that I’m appearing on your behalf at the arraignment. In propria persona.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: “In propria persona” means on your behalf.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 49.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: No, I’m saying it means on your behalf.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I am appearing on your behalf.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: “In propria persona” means that you’re appearing on your behalf, not my behalf.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (beat) I’ll check that out but the point is I’m not your lawyer and I’1l make that clear for the record. He stops her before they walk into the courtroom and show little compassion... CHARLIE (CONT’D) Look...my office’ll give you a list of names when we’re done. There are plenty of firms that’ll just be happy for the exposure. You'll be fine.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I appreciate it.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (pause) Alright. It’s a scary room. Don’t be scared.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Charlie, I know what’s what, okay? CHARLIE opens the courtroom door and holds it for MOLLY a the TWO BODYGUARDS as they walk into--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The courtroom is huge and ornate and right now it’s a bit a spectacle. On the right side of the gallery are the defendants and t lawyers--about 60 people in all. Behind a plexiglass partition are some more defendants in prison coveralls an shackles. The defendants range in age from early-20’s to 80's.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 50. On the left side of the gallery are the wives and girlfri of the defendants. They’re all beautifully dressed and manicured and have on some of their gaudiest jewelry for occasion. Seated in back of them are the press and it was a tough ticket to get. At the prosecutor’s table are three Assistant U.S. Attorn including HARRISON WELLSTONE, the lead attorney on the ca who we’ll get to know later. JUDGE DUSTIN FOXMAN is already seated at the bench and is quietly going over some business with the prosecutors as packed courtroom hums with quiet chatter. CHARLIE points a bodyguard to where he wants Molly to sit four taped off seats on the right side toward the back. A MOLLY and the BODYGUARDS take their seats, CHARLIE stands the aisle a moment and looks at HARRISON, the lead prosecutor. HARRISON turns back from the bench and heads his table and sees Charlie. HARRISON half-smiles and give CHARLIE a small wave. CHARLIE gives him a small wave back takes his seat on the aisle next to one of the bodyguards MOLLY’s clocked all that.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (quietly to MOLLY) You got a good judge, he’s a good guy.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: How ‘bout the prosecutor? CHARLIE takes a moment and then shakes his head “no”. JUDGE FOXMAN raps his gavel once, the room quiets down, a everyone takes their seats.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE FOXMAN
dialogues.text: Counsel, please state your appearances for the record?

dialogues.speaker: HARRISON
dialogues.text: Good morning, Your Honor, Harrison Wellstone and Jack Brennan on behalf of the Government, joined at counsel table by FBI Agent Deborah D’Angelo.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE FOXMAN
dialogues.text: Are there any oral motions at this time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He OK  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 51. One of the defense lawyers stands up--

dialogues.speaker: MR. SERNOVITZ
dialogues.text: Your Honor-- The seemingly routine business of the hearing continues u the following--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (quietly to the bodyguard) Switch with me a second. CHARLIE and the BODYGUARD switch places so that Charlie’s sitting next to Molly now. CHARLIE (CONT’D) (quietly) Do you know what a “Vor v Zakone” is? A “Vor"?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: The literal translation is “thief- in-law.” It’s the Russian equivalent of a Don or a Godfather. Nikolai Illyanovich is a Vor. He's the one who tried to fix the Salt Lake City Olympics.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I wasn’t there.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: He’s also had a lot of people killed. It’s basically do what I’m telling you or we’ll kill your kids.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I've never had an audience with the Vor, I’m not a made man and I don’t know who Nikolai Illyanovich is.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (pointing to a man behind the plexiglass) He’s standing right there. I can introduce you guys, you’re co- defendants. (to the BODYGUARD) Switch back.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 52. CHARLIE and the BODYGUARD switch back to their original seats. The business of the court continues.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Defendant 4, Jonathan Hirsch.

dialogues.speaker: SIEGEL
dialogues.text: Good morning, Your Honor. David Siegel for the purposes of today’s appearance.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE FOXMAN
dialogues.text: Has the defendant seen a copy of the indictment?

dialogues.speaker: HIRSCH
dialogues.text: Yes, Your Honor.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE FOXMAN
dialogues.text: Have you discussed it with your lawyer?

dialogues.speaker: HIRSCH
dialogues.text: I have.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE FOXMAN
dialogues.text: Do you waive its public reading?

dialogues.speaker: HIRSCH
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE FOXMAN
dialogues.text: How do you plead at this time?

dialogues.speaker: HIRSCH
dialogues.text: Not Guilty.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE FOXMAN
dialogues.text: Thank you, you may be seated.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Defendant 5, Arthur Azen. The court’s business continues as--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (whispering to the

dialogues.speaker: BODYGUARD
dialogues.text: Switch with me. CHARLIE and the BODYGUARD switch seats again and CHARLIE speaks quietly to MOLLY--  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 53. CHARLIE (CONT’D) Just in case your lawyer doesn’t mention it, the next time you appear in front of the judge you should re-think your clothes. You look like the Cinemax version of yourself.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I sold my clothes after the government seized all my money two years ago which incidentally was the last time I ran a poker game but I think I mentioned that already.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (beat) Okay. (pause--then quietly) Your old boss--the one you call Reardon--he was kind of a jerk to you. Why would you cover for him by changing it to “poor people bagels”? ee OK

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (quietly) I promise it couldn’t matter less.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (shrugs) * Just making conversation. *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE’s not really satisfied but he taps the bodyguard they switch back.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE FOXMAN
dialogues.text: Do you waive its public reading?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE FOXMAN
dialogues.text: How do you plead at this time?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Not guilty.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Defendant 7, Molly Bloom. MOLLY and CHARLIE stand and when they do, everyone in the courtroom turns around to get a look at the Poker Princes  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy)

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Good morning, Your Honor. Charles Jaffey, just for the purposes-- And CHARLIE stops mid-sentence and thinks...

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE FOXMAN
dialogues.text: (pause) It’s good to see you, Mr. Jaffey, are you with us this morning? (beat) Mr. Jaffey?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Just a moment please, sir. (to the BODYGUARD) Switch back. They switch--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Seriously?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You said you left ten-times that much on the street. Back at my office. I said it’s a $250,000 retainer and you said you left ten times that on the street.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE FOXMAN
dialogues.text: Counsel, I need to record your appearance.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Please the Court Your Honor, just one moment. (to Molly) You were extending credit. You’re destitute and you left two anda half million dollars on the street?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I had to.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Didn’t anyone try to buy your debt sheet?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Everyone tried to buy my debt sheet, is this the right time to-- 54.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy)

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you sell it like you sold your clothes?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I couldn't.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I couldn’t be sure how they were gonna collect.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (pause) I was afraid you were gonna say that.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE FOXMAN
dialogues.text: Counsel? CHARLIE thinks...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (pause) Charles Jaffey for the defendant, Your Honor.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE FOXMAN
dialogues.text: For the purposes of this hearing only?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No sir, I’m Molly Bloom’s attorney. She’s read the indictment, discussed it with her lawyer, waives her right to have it read to her and pleads “Not Guilty”. HARRISON clocks this, smiles and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Defendant 8, Alexander Gollib.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I'll need to keep reading your book.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 56.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: There was a track star from Pasadena in the 1930s named Matthew Robinson.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Matthew Robinson shattered the Olympic record in the two-hundred at the Berlin Games in 1936. Absolutely shattered the Olympic * record...and came in second. * We PULL BACK and see that another runner finished just ah of him. *

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The man who came in first was Jesse Owens.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Owens went on to be a legend. *

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Matthew Robinson went on to be a janitor at a whites-only school in Pasadena. The difference was two- * hundreths of a second. *
