dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: As if that wasn’t enough, Matthew Robinson had a little brother who was also an athlete. We PULL BACK on the photo and see the runner sliding into home has the number 42 on his back and the umpire is * signaling that he’s safe. *

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: His name was Jack but everyone called him Jackie.

dialogues.speaker: FOOTAGE OF JEREMY BLOOM RACING THROUGH MOGULS, (FILE)
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 57.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I have two younger brothers who were also overachievers. While I was ranked 3rd in North America, my brother Jeremy was Number 1 in the world.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: And while I was placing into A.P. Chemistry as a junior, my brother Jordan was doing it when he was 12- years-old or something, I don’t know. MOLLY’S CHILDHOOD HOUSE - NIGHT Molly, now 15, is having dinner with her FATHER, MOTHER, two YOUNGER BROTHERS.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I was a hotshot student and a hotshot skier everywhere but my own house. And that’s where we live. As I got older I began to bait my father into fights without really knowing why I was doing it.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Let’s go around the table. Impress me with what you learned at school today. Jeremy Bloom.

dialogues.speaker: JEREMY, (YOUNGEST BROTHER)
dialogues.text: The usual stuff.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Usual stuff. Jordan Bloom.

dialogues.speaker: JORDAN, (MIDDLE KID)
dialogues.text: Usual stuff.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: I am impressed. Molly?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: I learned that Sigmund Freud was both a misogynist and an idiot and that anyone who relies on his theories of human psychology is a quack. The FATHER laughs a little and the MOTHER looks nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 58.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: I don’t know why you'd say that.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: You asked me what I learned in school today.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Is this Mrs. Linwood?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Did she happen to mention anything about his work on the unconscious mind?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: His dream analysis has the credibility of a horoscope but what got my attention was that he opposed the women’s emancipation movement. He believed that a woman's life is about their reproductive functions.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: So you were really getting to the nuts and bolts of why middle-class, suburban white girls have been oppressed for centuries.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Mrs. Linwood--

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Barbara Linwood doesn’t like men, Molly.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: She doesn’t like dicks, Dad, there’s a difference. The FATHER looks at MOLLY then throws his fork down on hi plate with a frightening clang.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Molly, don’t say things like--

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Don’t disrespect me like that at the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 59.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: I wasn’t disrespecting you, I was disrespecting Freud and it’s a kitchen table, it’s not the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: And I’m a professional psychologist, not a quack.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: I never said (you were a)--

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: (over) Yeah you did and don’t do it again and don’t ever use that language again.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Okay, ignore my teachers, watch my language and respect the kitchen table. What else do I need to do before I’m allowed to disagree with you?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Make your own money so you can live in your own house and eat your own food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOLLY counts out a big stack of hundreds.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I'd been running the game for 13 months and saved twenty-eight thousand dollars. REARDON counts two stacks of chips and throws them in the pot.

dialogues.speaker: REARDON
dialogues.text: Call.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I was recruiting and vetting players, keeping the books, collecting and delivering checks--  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 60.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER X
dialogues.text: Straight to the eight. PLAYER X won and REARDON lost.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: --meeting the needs of all the players throughout the week and still working full-time for Reardon, who’d made it clear that if I quit the office job I’d lose the game. REARDON picks up what’s left of his chips--

dialogues.speaker: REARDON
dialogues.text: I’m done. Reardon gets called “Pussy” and other names before the players go back to their own conversations and Reardon ma his way over to Molly. He puts his chips down in front of which Molly skillfully stacks, counts, and types into her spreadsheet as she says--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (quietly) I thought he had trips too. He was slow-playing into the river and he hid the pocket 3 pretty well. Tough beat. You owe the game--

dialogues.speaker: REARDON
dialogues.text: I know what I owe the game, I want to talk to you a minute.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (beat) Okay.

dialogues.speaker: REARDON
dialogues.text: Outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A band is loading out its equipment into a couple of wait vans. A back door opens and REARDON comes out, followed b MOLLY.

dialogues.speaker: REARDON
dialogues.text: Is he cheating?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: REARDON
dialogues.text: How would you know?  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 61.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I'd know.

dialogues.speaker: REARDON
dialogues.text: He and Diego aren’t in bed together?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: REARDON
dialogues.text: What about him and you?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (beat) If you’re asking what I think you're asking, no. In fact there’s nothing you could be asking where it wouldn’t be no. A fifty-two card deck produces hundreds of millions of random patterns but every time one of you loses two weeks in a row you’re sure something fishy must be up.

dialogues.speaker: REARDON
dialogues.text: I’m gonna stop paying you.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: REARDON
dialogues.text: As my assistant.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You're firing me?

dialogues.speaker: REARDON
dialogues.text: I’m not firing you, I'm just gonna stop paying you. You get paid once a week from the game, it doesn’t seem fair.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: But I also have a job working for you 24 hours a day.

dialogues.speaker: REARDON
dialogues.text: And if you didn’t have that job you wouldn’t have the game, you understand what I’m saying?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (pause) I understand each of the words that you’re saying, but--  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy)

dialogues.speaker: REARDON
dialogues.text: Look--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: 24 hours a day every day. You’re gonna stop paying me to do that job because I’m making too much money doing my second job and if I say no I'll lose both jobs. Because it doesn’t seem fair?

dialogues.speaker: REARDON
dialogues.text: Business is bad right now, welcome to the real world. MOLLY takes a moment and then goes for it--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Alright, here it is: Banks are loaning you money and they shouldn’t. You’re a bad risk, they know that. So the debt service on your loans is close to 20 percent which is crazy. 20 percent is barely survivable if it’s a bridge loan but, for instance, it’s taken you 10 years to build seven houses, all of which are worth less than they were before you built them because the housing market’s on a downward trajectory for the first time in the history of houses and that’s why business is bad, not because you pay me four-hundred and fifty dollars a week.

dialogues.speaker: REARDON
dialogues.text: You're a business savant?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I've read every piece of paper in your office.

dialogues.speaker: REARDON
dialogues.text: You’re making thousands in tips every week, why do you care about (four-hundred and fifty dollars a week?)

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (over) I care about it because I don’t want to pick up your dry cleaning for free.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 63.

dialogues.speaker: REARDON
dialogues.text: You don’t have bargaining power here. You can refuse the pay cut but you’ll lose the game. (handing her a few chips) Cash me out please. REARDON heads back inside and Molly stands there alone a moment...

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: There’s an old saying:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a VALET opens Molly’s car door and MOLLY, looking fantastic in business clothes, steps out.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “Never wait until your ski releases before you check to see if a small pine bough’s in your way.” I don’t know how old that saying is but I wasn’t going to wait for Reardon to take the game away before I put a plan in place. MOLLY’s met by a HOTEL MANAGER.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The next morning I made appointments at the Four Seasons, the Peninsula and the Beverly Hills Hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MANAGER is showing MOLLY the expensive suite with beautiful views.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: The suite was fifty-two hundred a night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As DIEGO fits a Shuffle Master into the hole that’s been into the table.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 64.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I spent seventeen-thousand on a Shuffle Master that was installed in the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The view is even more spectacular and glamorous at night. Delicious food is being put on small tables between the s by an attractive server.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Food was brought in from Mr. Chow and available to eat on side tables. An equally attractive BARTENDER is preparing the bar.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: There was Macallan 18, Belvedere, 1942, Remy Martin, and an ‘88 Lafite Rothschild served by a bartender who’d already memorized your drink. Cohibas and Monte Cristos were in the humidor and two licensed massage therapists were there to rub your shoulders as you played.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOLLY’s having her hair blown out while working a spreads on her laptop. An outfit is being laid out on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: A professional stylist turned me into what my defense attorney would later call the Cinemax version of myself. I spent almost everything I had in preparation for the phone call I new was coming. We HEAR a cell phone ring before we--

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 65.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOLLY rolls over in bed and looks at the ringing cell pho It’s Reardon.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello? REARDON doesn’t sound good.

dialogues.speaker: REARDON, (OVER THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: I want you to listen to me. ‘Cause you need to hear this.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (pause) Are you alright?

dialogues.speaker: REARDON, (OVER THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: Are you listening? You need to hear this.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: REARDON, (OVER THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: I need to tell you something in plain English and I need to know that you understood it.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: REARDON, (OVER THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: You are unimportant, did you hear me? And you are fired. (pause) Did you hear me? The job, the game, you're fired.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Why don’t you lie down for a while.

dialogues.speaker: REARDON, (OVER THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: You're fired, Molly.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Can I ask why?

dialogues.speaker: REARDON
dialogues.text: You were supposed to set up the TV.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 66.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I did, I installed it myself.

dialogues.speaker: REARDON, (OVER THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: I’m looking at a blank screen.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I told you yesterday your cable would be out until 10am today.

dialogues.speaker: REARDON, (OVER THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: It was your responsibility.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I told you there would be cable outages in your area. It’ll be back on by 10am. I don’t have control over Comcast.

dialogues.speaker: REARDON, (OVER THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: How many of my friends are you sleeping with?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I’m not sleeping with any of them.

dialogues.speaker: REARDON, (OVER THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: That’s not what I heard.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Reardon, listen to me, with a hazmat suit I wouldn’t sleep with-- just lie down.

dialogues.speaker: REARDON, (OVER THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: Can I give you some advice? Lose the bitchy air. Lose the superior air. Go to the office and get your stuff and be out of there before I show up. REARDON hangs up and we --

dialogues.speaker: BLUEROCK OFFICES
dialogues.text: an attractive young woman, is putting the last of Molly’s things in a box when MOLLY walks into the office.

dialogues.speaker: LEAH
dialogues.text: Hi. Are you Molly?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 67.

dialogues.speaker: LEAH
dialogues.text: I’m Leah. Reardon asked me to pack your personals.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I appreciate it.

dialogues.speaker: LEAH
dialogues.text: He also asked me to get the numbers of tonight’s players so I can confirm the list for tonight. I’m really sorry.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Don’t be. My phone’s in my car. I’ll text you all the numbers you need when I get downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOLLY’s got her box of stuff from the office next to her the passenger seat as she pulls into the Four Seasons and met by the hotel manager.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I texted my replacement a bunch of random numbers with 310 area codes. Then I sent a text to the players for tonight and told them the game had been moved to the Four Seasons Hotel, Suite 1401.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The players are sitting and standing around, drinking champagne and cocktails, smoking a cigar, standing on the terrace, etc. The place looks beautiful and so does MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Fellas, can I have your attention a moment?

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER
dialogues.text: Where’s Reardon?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I'll be hosting a game in this suite every Tuesday night. If you play tonight you’ll be guaranteed a seat at the game for life. If you’d prefer to play at the Viper Room there'll be no hard feelings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 68. There’s quiet for a moment and everyone kind of looks at PLAYER X...PLAYER X looks at MOLLY and smiles, who looks at him...blank but confident. *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The game is in full swing and high spirits. MOLLY and her laptop are observing from a little distance.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: The game was mine now. I incorporated and MDB Event Planning was born. I paid taxes and 1099'’d my employees. I never became romantically or sexually involved with any of the players. It just wouldn’t have been professional-- this was back when I was still making good decisions. And I went to a lawyer to make absolutely sure all this was legal. INT. LOUIS BUTTERMAN’S OFFICE - DAY * MOLLY sits across from LOUIS BUTTERMAN, a lawyer. *

dialogues.speaker: BUTTERMAN
dialogues.text: Are you taking a rake?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BUTTERMAN
dialogues.text: Then you’re not breaking the law * but can I give you some advice? *

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Please. *

dialogues.speaker: BUTTERMAN
dialogues.text: There’s a saying in my business. * Don’t break the law when you’re breaking the law.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: BUTTERMAN
dialogues.text: No drugs, no prostitutes, no muscle to collect debts.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I don’t do anything like that but you just said I wasn’t breaking the law.

dialogues.speaker: BUTTERMAN
dialogues.text: Let’s keep it that way, ‘cause you don’t want to break the law when you’re breaking the law.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (beat) Am I breaking the law?

dialogues.speaker: BUTTERMAN
dialogues.text: Not really.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: We're able to find out for sure, aren’t we? Laws are written down.

dialogues.speaker: BUTTERMAN
dialogues.text: You're not taking a percentage of the pot?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: No

dialogues.speaker: BUTTERMAN
dialogues.text: You’re running a square game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A game is underway and it looks like everything Molly’s describing.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My game had a tricky ecosystem. It was built around escapism and exclusivity. These guys could buy their way into anything and anyone but here in this room you couldn’t buy your win. You couldn’t buy me, you couldn’t buy the girls and you couldn’t buy a seat at the table. There’s nothing as sweet as a win you have to work for and the wins and losses were compelling and they were real. Of course it helped that the players were gambling addicts.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The game has ended. Diego’s breaking down the table, the women are cleaning up and PLAYER X is talking to MOLLY.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER X
dialogues.text: I've had a thought.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER X
dialogues.text: Raise the stakes.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (pause) To what?

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER X
dialogues.text: 50K buy-in. Blinds are five-hundred and a thousand.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (pause) That’s uh...that’s a 500 percent hike.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER X
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I don’t think it’s a good idea.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER X
dialogues.text: (calling out) Could you give me the room a second? They wait for the women to leave the room...

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: The players who are losing a hundred-thousand a week are gonna be losing half a million.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER X
dialogues.text: And the players winning a hundred- thousand--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: --will have no one left to play with. Players are gonna get hurt, others are gonna get killed and some of them are gonna drop out. It’s not sustainable and we’ll lose the game.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 71.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER X
dialogues.text: Find new players.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: He meant find new fish and with these stakes that was gonna be challenging. First up was Donnie Silverman.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Donnie won the World Series of Poker last year and got in touch with me through one of the players. INT. MOLLY’S APARTMENT/LIVING ROOM - NIGHT MOLLY’s watching the World Series of Poker on her laptop. can see that DONNIE’s one of the players as MOLLY hits pa makes a note on a pad and then continues watching.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Ordinarily if you were at the final table at the World Series that would automatically disqualify you from playing in my game but a Vegas contact told me to look at the film. So that night I watched seven hours of the world’s worst spectator sport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOLLY’s standing with a check for PLAYER X.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER X
dialogues.text: Are you fuckin’ nuts? Donnie Silverman won the World Series of Poker.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: He took eleven hands at the final table. He had the nuts on eight of them and three of those--three-- were two-outers with four players still in the hand. He ran hot. He doesn’t lock his chips down, he’s reckless, gives tons of action and just won 12-million dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 72.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER X
dialogues.text: (beat) Okey-doke.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Next up was Harlan Eustis. MOLLY’s watching HARLAN play at one of the tables. He’s g big stack of chips in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Player X said he met him at the Commerce Casino and that he'd be good for the game but I wasn’t seeing what he was seeing. He played tight, folding after the hole cards 64 percent of the time. HARLAN tosses his cards into the middle of the table.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It wasn’t clear where his money came from. He produced backyard wrestling videos and other low-rent productions--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --as HARLAN wins the hand and pulls in his chips.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: --but worst of all, Harlan Eustice was a good card player. And Player X knew he was good but he wanted him anyway and he wanted him badly. You'll see why in a moment. a *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 73.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two men in their 30’s, BRAD and NEAL, are walking on the beach toward the house and we move in on BRAD--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: The third new recruit was Brad Marion, who everyone called Bad Brad because he was uniquely terrible at this game. If there was a worse player in the world, Brad would still find a way to lose to him. As BRAD and NEAL get closer to the house we can see bikin clad women and a few guys partying around the hot tub.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I'd been asked to throw together a game on a Saturday night at the Malibu house of a man who made his money by co-starring in a sex video opposite a woman who made her money by being born with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A game is underway. BRAD waits in the doorway and watches game as NEAL approaches MOLLY.

dialogues.speaker: NEAL
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Hey, what are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: NEAL
dialogues.text: I’m three houses down. Derrick said you were having a game and I wanted to-- MOLLY puts her finger up to say, “Just a second.” She wat the end of the hand play out.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (back to Neal) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: NEAL
dialogues.text: I just wanted to introduce you to Brad Marion, he wants to play.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Well if you give me his information I’ll check him out. Ce ee a

dialogues.speaker: HO FHF
dialogues.text: He OF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 74.

dialogues.speaker: NEAL
dialogues.text: No, Derrick’s gonna vouch for him. MOLLY looks at BRAD, a sweet if slightly odd guy with a slight facial tic. He’s looking at the game like a kid in candy store. Then she steps over to one of the players-- DERRICK--and whispers in his ear.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: “Derrick’s gonna vouch for him” meant Derrick would cover any losses if Brad didn’t pay. Up to any amount. DERRICK nods his head “yes” without taking his eyes off t table. MOLLY looks at BRAD again, then waves him over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A game is underway and BRAD’s playing now.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But he could pay, and did. As we go through a SERIES OF CUTS showing BRAD betting hu stacks of chips, losing, buying in from MOLLY for another 50K, betting huge, losing, etc.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Bad Brad had raised 45-million dollars for a fund that traded oil futures and every week he came to the game, lost a quarter of a million dollars and tipped me 10- thousand so he could play the next week. He wasn’t getting any better and the guys were feasting on him. BRAD loses another hand and walks over to Molly’s table.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Can I get another fifty?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Hey, let’s talk for a second.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Brad, this game may not be for you.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: I know I’m no card shark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oe OF He HH HH HK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 75.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: No, you’re not. MOLLY shows BRAD her computer screen--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: These are your losses after ten weeks. And you’ve won...never. The strongest players have losing weeks and the weaker players get lucky but I’ve never seen someone not win, you know, ever. It’s actually a statistical anomaly.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Yeah I know. I like playing with the guys. I don’t have that many friends. Don’t take my seat away, I can tip you more.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: No, your tips are very generous. How about if I got you some books to read? Or even a pro to give you lessons?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Sure. Maybe. Let me think about it.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (pause) Okay. Sign for fifty-thousand. MOLLY pulls chips while BRAD signs on a clipboard.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Turned out Bad Brad knew what he was doing. He was getting customers. He’d drop 200K at the game and pick up two-million for his hedge fund. DERRICK slaps BRAD on the back--

dialogues.speaker: DERRICK
dialogues.text: Tell ‘em what’s smart this week.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: More on that later as well but first the final recruit.

dialogues.speaker: HO HH HK
dialogues.text: ee OK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He OK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 76. EXT. DODGER STADIUM/OWNER’S LUXURY BOX - NIGHT MOLLY and some other nicely-dressed people are watching t game in style but at this moment they’re standing in nerv anticipation. Some of the people are holding hands for lu and a couple are covering their eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I was in the owner’s box at Dodger Stadium when People Magazine's Sexiest Man Alive called me. I was dating the owners’ son at the time and the night before we’d had a discussion about priorities. INT. BOYFRIEND’S BEDROOM - NIGHT The BOYFRIEND’s in bed as MOLLY comes into the darkened r dressed for the poker game she’s just come from.

dialogues.speaker: BOYFRIEND
dialogues.text: It’s 4:30 in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (quietly) Hey babe, I’m sorry to wake you up.

dialogues.speaker: BOYFRIEND
dialogues.text: You didn’t wake me up, I’ve been waiting up.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You shouldn’t have, that’s why I have a key.

dialogues.speaker: BOYFRIEND
dialogues.text: I don’t know any other guy who’d put up with his girlfriend staying out till 4:30. Dressing like that for millionaire movie stars, being the only woman in the room--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I didn’t realize until just now that you’re mad.

dialogues.speaker: BOYFRIEND
dialogues.text: When you’re not running a game you’re out recruiting, you sleep-- when you sleep--you have two phones clutched to your chest, you went out in the middle of the night last night, I don’t even know where--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 77.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: It was to pick up a check from a player. I got a call.

dialogues.speaker: BOYFRIEND
dialogues.text: You couldn’t pick up the check in the morning?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You can’t let a gambler sleep ona debt.

dialogues.speaker: BOYFRIEND
dialogues.text: I don’t think this argument’s gonna get me anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You want to have sex like we’re strangers?

dialogues.speaker: BOYFRIEND
dialogues.text: I want to make this work!

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Okay. Okay. I do too. And tomorrow night I’m gonna come with you to the game and I’m not gonna make any calls or take any calls and I’m gonna make a good impression on your parents. I’m gonna be there just for you.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I over-promised. EXT. DODGER STADIUM/OWNER’S LUXURY BOX - NIGHT Back with MOLLY, her BOYFRIEND, the PARENTS and other gue some of whom are praying or covering their eyes, etc.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: ‘Cause the thing is if you’re sitting in the owner’s box with the owners, who are also your boyfriend’s parents-- We see hits of the scoreboard that demonstrate what Molly talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 78.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: --and your team is batting in the bottom of the ninth, down by a run, one out, runners on first and third and a win means you’re in the playoffs, you’re really not at that moment supposed to take a phone call. MOLLY’s phone buzzes and she sneaks a peak at the caller The BOYFRIEND clocks this.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I wanted this man in the game, and not because he was People’s Sexiest Man Alive. I already had three of them at the table. But this one was a heavyweight--one of the biggest stars in the world. A 9-time Grammy winner whose last two albums debuted at Number-1 on the Billboard chart. Smart, charismatic, and influential, he wasn’t a recluse but you didn’t see him at parties or clubs. He was powerful fish bait, he was whale bait, he was an actual rock star and he was good business. And if I had him as an ally I wouldn’t be dependant on Player xX. MOLLY makes her decision, takes out her phone, tells her BOYFRIEND she’s sorry and she’ll be just a second and get the reaction you’d expect.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I'll call him Player Y.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (into phone) This is Molly.

dialogues.speaker: THE VIEW, (FILE FOOTAGE)
dialogues.text: They come back from commercial with bumper music and animation. JENNY MCCARTHY is introducing their next guest with a giant copy of Molly’s Game projected on the rear screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: eK eK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 79.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY MCCARTHY
dialogues.text: Molly Bloom was dubbed the Poker Princess for running underground high stakes poker games for Hollywood superstars, Wall Street big wigs--

dialogues.speaker: AMY ROBACH
dialogues.text: The new book, Molly’s Game, just out today, is already making headlines with big stories in Vanity Fair and People Magazine.

dialogues.speaker: 20/20, (FILE FOOTAGE)
dialogues.text: Over a montage of seedy-nightlife-in-LA shots--

dialogues.speaker: VOICE OVER
dialogues.text: In the heart of Hollywood, hidden beneath the notorious Viper Room, a narrow hallway leads into a musty room, a poker table, and the secret life of Molly Bloom. We hear MOLLY’s voice off screen--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Not as secret as I'd hoped. We pull back and we’re in-- INT. CHARLIE’S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS --as CHARLIE clicks off the TV. Molly’s standing in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Hey. C’mon in. Throw your coat anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: How was your flight?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Just fine.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: How are you paying for plane tickets between LA and New York?  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy)

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I had two-million points left on my AmEx. They took away the card but they let me keep the points which I thought was nice of them.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It was. So you had meetings.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Hm?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You had meetings out in LA about the book?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I did.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: With the studios.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yes. And a few other people.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You have an agent working with you?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Was there interest?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: A company that owns 400,000 video poker machines wants to put my face on them.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Anything else?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Treat Magazine made a generous offer.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Treat?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: It’s a new magazine for the high- end photography enthusiast. 80.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 81.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: They want you to pose naked.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I'd be the April treat.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I meant interest in the book.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Any offers?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: A few I guess. A couple. Seven.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Really.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: And...?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I passed.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You passed on seven offers.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You will be paid, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No, I’m just curious why you passed on seven offers.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Creative differences. Should we start?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Okay, you see this? CHARLIE’s motioned to a stack of documents-- CHARLIE (CONT’D) This is discovery. Let’s see what we've discovered. CHARLIE will draw a crude diagram on a white board as he speaks.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 82. CHARLIE (CONT’D) Over here we have Michael Druzhinsky, Michael Anikovich and Michael Slobo. The three Mikes. CHARLIE draws three “M”s and puts a circle around it. * CHARLIE (CONT’D) The three Mikes run a chain of corrupt medical clinics and they’ve been committing insurance fraud, wire fraud and mail fraud on an epic scale. Over here is the Taiwanchik-Gershen Organization. * CHARLIE writes “TGO” and draws a circle around it. * CHARLIE (CONT’D) They’re a worldwide bookmaking operation handling hundreds of millions of dollars a year in illegal sports betting. And over here is the Habib-Gershen * Organization. * CHARLIE writes “HGO” and draws a circle around it. The th organizations are now in a triangle on the white board. CHARLIE (CONT’D) Also an illegal bookmaking operation but this one financed by an art gallery owned by Hillel Habib who everyone calls-- *

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Helly. MOLLY and CHARLIE both understand that MOLLY just admitte knowing these guys.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (pause) This is the Russian mafia. And the three are tied together in the indictment through...? A poker game. CHARLIE writes “Molly” in the middle of the triangle and draws a circle around it.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Were they tapping my phone?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy)

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Thank God.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: They were tapping the phones of everyone you talked to.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Druzhinsky’s phone was tapped. They’ve got you confirming that you ran raked games at various locations in New York and they've also got a confidential informant confirming that you ran raked games at various locations in New York. You were in violation of 1955-- that’s the part of the U.S. Code that makes it illegal to run an illegal gambling business. (pause) You know what you did? You finished writing your book before the good part happened.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You get a kick outta yourself, don’t you. CHARLIE lifts up a copy of Molly’s Game--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I don’t like this picture.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You look like the cat who ate the canary and then told the canary’s parents about it.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I don’t like it either but it’s the picture the publisher wanted and I wasn’t given a vote.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I liked the book though. A good story well told.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Thank you. 83.  84.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I need you to tell it again. From the beginning and this time without leaving anything out. Would you like a glass of water?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I'd like a glass of bourbon.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: And one more thing.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I need your hard drives.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Going back how far?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I kept my hard drives when I'd buy a new laptop.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You’re kidding.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: It had records of who owed what and spreadsheets on the players.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: They have more than that. Every time you charge your phone by plugging it into your computer the computer records all your text messages and e-mails.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (pause) Are you joking?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I want to run a forensic imaging of your hard drives.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: No, I’ll be destroying those hard drives.  85.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You can’t, they’re evidence.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I’m going to blow them up. I’m literally going to use explosives and then scatter the remains in the Colorado River.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You already told me they exist.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You’re just gonna have to pretend I didn’t tell you.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I can’t do that.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I don’t have any hard drives, I work with an abacus.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Molly--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: There are no hard drives!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: If you destroy evidence and obstruct justice on top of the charges already brought against you in this case, you will, I promise you, be incarcerated.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You don’t understand what’s in those text messages.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I understand that you’ve had boyfriends and that there are gonna be private exchanges.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You don’t understand. There are going to be those messages and they’1ll be embarrassing but there are also going to be messages that would destroy lives. Other lives. There are messages that would end careers and obliterate families. If the text messages were made public--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: They won't be.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 86.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: If they were--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: They won't be.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: --it would be catastrophic for many people.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I’m a lawyer. I’m legally--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Listen to me, I’m legally prohibited from disclosing--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: My last lawyer sold my deposition to the National Enquirer, Charlie! (beat) That happened. But the information in that deposition will be nothing compared to the consequences of those text messages--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Hang on. CHARLIE walks to his desk and picks up his copy of Molly’ Game.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Children will find out their fathers--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: The movie stars you named in the book--you’d already named them under oath in the Bad Brad Marion deposition.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: It was that or perjure myself and Brad had already named everyone in the game.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: That’s not what I’m getting at. Your lawyer back then--Butterball--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Butterman.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 87.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Butterman leaked your deposition to the tabloids?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yeah. CHARLIE nods that now he understands...

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: That’s why those were the only real names you used in the book, the ones that were given up by Butterbean.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: And is that why you have creative differences with the Hollywood offers? They want information you won’t give them?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: None of this has anything to do with the Russian mob, right?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What’s on the hard drives, Molly? Famous married guys hitting on you? MOLLY nods her head “yeah”. CHARLIE picks up his cell phone and tosses it to her.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: What’s this?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It’s got every e-mail and text message I’ve sent in the last year as well as a variety of incriminating evidence about my clients. If anything of yours leaks you can sell my phone to the highest bidder and I'll lose my job and be disbarred.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 88.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: In order to demonstrate the sanctity of your attorney/client confidentiality you’re betraying the confidentiality of all your other clients?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I know you’re not gonna read it. If you're having a hard time trusting me, maybe it’ll help to know I trust you. MOLLY takes a long moment before she says--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I’ll fly home to Colorado and be back the next day with the hard drives. MOLLY tosses Charlie’s phone back to him.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Here’s how I lost the LA game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARLAN EUSTICE stares silently at cards we can’t see. The explodes--

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: Motherfucker! HARLAN’s frozen in furious silence for a moment. The othe players are quiet and don’t look at him. HARLAN grabs som food that’s on a plate and throws it at DIEGO--

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fuck you! DIEGO is professional and doesn’t react.

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fuck you, you Mexican fuck! HARLAN doesn’t get far in his tirade before MOLLY quickly steps in and defuses the situation.

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You undocumented fucking border jumping fuck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 89.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Hey HEY! (to Harlan) You get out on the terrace.

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: (to DIEGO) You’ve been pullin’ that shit all night!

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (to HARLAN) Out on the terrace. Now. MOLLY motions to CASSIE, the relief dealer, the way a baseball manager would motion to the bullpen. MOLLY walks DIEGO away from the table--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (quietly) You good?

dialogues.speaker: DIEGO
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Have a drink. MOLLY goes out on to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --where HARLAN’s waiting.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: What the hell.

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: I’ll apologize to Diego.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yeah and you’re gonna go home, I’m making a floor call, that’s it. HARLAN doesn’t say anything--he just stares out at Los Angeles...

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (pause) Did you hear me?

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: I don’t have it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 90.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (beat) You don’t have what? HARLAN looks at MOLLY very simply...

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: The million-two, I don’t have it. MOLLY takes that in...

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: It was 5am on Saturday. This game began at 7pm on Thursday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone’s much fresher and more energetic. DIEGO’s deali

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: I rented out the whole courtyard of the Buffalo Club, it’1ll be about a hundred people. Kumamoto oysters, snow crab, lobsters--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Harlan Eustice was the producer of backyard wrestling videos who Player X badly wanted in the game. Harlan was excited about the surprise 40th birthday party he was throwing for his wife in 24 hours.

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: Kobe beef, black truffle pasta, Dover sole--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I liked Harlan. There was no affectation, no Hollywooding, no flossing--he wasn’t ticking off the menu items to show off, he was genuinely excited about the party he was giving his wife.

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: She doesn’t know anything, she thinks we’re having dinner with her brother and his wife.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: But nobody else liked him except Player X. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 91.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He played tight, didn’t give a lot of action and always got his money in good which means he was running the odds. In other words he was playing poker and the others were gambling. In a SERIES OF SHOTS we see HARLAN folding hands--

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: (tossing in his cards) Fold.

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fold.

dialogues.speaker: LATER--
dialogues.text: HARLAN tosses in his cards--

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (tossing his cards) Nope.

dialogues.speaker: LATER--
dialogues.text: HARLAN hauls in a huge pile of chips after a win.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And he won.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CASSIE’s dealing in the middle of a hand. There’s already small pot in the middle and the only two players left are HARLAN and BRAD. The four cards turned over in the middle queen-eight-nine-nine.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: By midnight Harlan had tripled his original fifty-thousand dollar buy- in but everything came off the rails with one hand. And that’s how it happens, that’s how you go full tilt. Harlan, the best player at the table, the best player at most tables, was about to get bluffed off the nuts by, of all people, Bad Brad. CASSIE turns over a fifth card--a king. He OK  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 92.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: How? Because this was only Brad’s second game, Harlan hadn’t been at his first, and Harlan didn’t know yet that Brad was bad. Animation shows Harlan’s hand--an 8 and a 9--which when a to the table cards (KQ899) gives Harlan a full house.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Harlan’s got a boat, nine’s full. Animation shows Brad with a 3 and a 5, which when added t the table cards equals nothing.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Brad’s got nothing but his pre-flop betting made it look, entirely accidentally, like there was a chance he had pocket kings, which, if true, would give him the better full house. HARLAN counts his chips and pushes some into the pot--

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: 30-thousand. BRAD begins counting his chips.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: And there it is. Brad’s counting off 30-thousand which means he’s gonna call and Harlan knows that if Brad’s gonna call and not raise it means he didn’t have the boat and he’s betting a high two-pair-- probably kings and queens. But then instead of calling the bet-- BRAD pushes ALL his chips in--

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: I’m all in.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: --Brad pushes 72-thousand dollars into the pot. Harlan looks at Brad. Every tell Harlan knows about-- carotid artery pumping, stiff hands- -Brad’s doing the opposite. Harlan’s betting had represented a huge hand by calling on the flop, check-raising the turn and bombing the river. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy)

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Of course Harlan didn’t know that Brad didn’t know what any of that meant. So Harlan, always a good sport, said--

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: Nice bet. I’m laying this down.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: --as he tossed in what he didn’t realize was the winning hand. Brad tosses in his cards too and one of them flips over and Harlan sees it’s not a king.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Oh, sorry about that. HARLAN puts his finger on the flipped card to keep the de from collecting it.

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: You didn’t have pocket kings?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: I didn’t have any kings. Except the one in the middle.

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: You had two pair?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: I had one pair, the nines in the middle. Everyone starts laughing raucously at Harlan--asking “How could you fold that?!”, “Bill Buckner!”--further humiliat Harlan and patting Brad on the back. HARLAN is frozen. faced. MOLLY of course is clocking all this.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: It wasn’t even that it was that much money--Harlan only lost about 40-thousand on the hand-- HARLAN gets up and starts pacing around the room.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: --but a circuit breaker blew and Harlan was out for blood. Everyone's. HARLAN walks up to MOLLY--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 94,

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (quietly) You’ve got 51-thousand on the table, you want another 50?

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: Gimme another hundred.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (beat) Sign here for 100-thousand. MOLLY starts to pull the chips and we --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARLAN watches while another pair of hands haul in the po He gets up and goes to MOLLY.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: By 5am Harlan was down half a million. He'd abandoned everything he knew about poker and was playing like a frat kid--swinging for a home run on every hand.

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: Another hundred.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Harlan--

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: Molly. Please. Let’s go.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Sign here for a hundred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The staff closes the curtains to shut out the daylight. T NEW PLAYERS walk in, freshly dressed for work.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Text messages were going out letting everyone know Harlan was bleeding. Guys were coming by to play for a couple of hours before work. They'd been losing to him for months. Everyone wanted a check from Harlan Eustice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 95. HARLAN’s pouring himself a Red Bull and vodka as Molly wa up to him.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: If you go home now you can get a few hours sleep before Sheila’s party.

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: Soon.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You’re on tilt--everybody knows it. * And you're playing without the ammunition you need to win.

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: You’re right.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (beat) * Alright, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: Give me 500-thousand. MOLLY looks at him... *

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m just gonna get back to even. MOLLY looks at him and then pulls $500,000 in chips and * counts them for Harlan.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: That should be the second line of every gambler’s obit. “Mr. Feldstein died while trying to get back to even.” Harlan never did. And he never got to his wife’s birthday party. She filed for divorce two days later but there was one last punch coming that would put Harlan on the floor for good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The staff opens the curtains and it’s dark outside again. room service cart is being pushed into the hall by one of female staff. HARLAN and another player in his 30’s are the only two in hand but everyone’s watching with great interest.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 96.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Harlan was heads-up against a guy named Frederick who was Austrian royalty--the son of a Count in the House of Habsburg and a distant cousin of Marie Antoinette. Again, we see animation on the screen as MOLLY describes their hands.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Harlan had pocket queens. His Excellency had Ace-King. They were both in 65K pre-flop. DIEGO burns a card and then deals three in the middle.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: The flop’s queen-seven-seven. Harlan has a full-house again, queens full of sevens--with three rounds of betting in front of him. The Count has nothing. FREDERICK stacks his chips and pushes them all in.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And the Count goes all in. He wants Harlan to think he’s got two more sevens under there. Bite me, says Harlan, he’s not falling for this again and he snap calls all in. There’s $750,000 on the table. Diego burns a card and deals the turn. A king. Otto von Bismarck now has two pair, kings and sevens, but two-pair’s nothing next to a full house. And at this point, the only hand left that can beat a queen full house-- DIEGO turns over the fifth card. It’s a king--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: --is a king full house. Captain von Trapp bluffed two pair and rivered into kings full! Then all of a sudden--

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: Motherfucker! We're back at the scene we saw before. HARLAN’s frozen in furious silence for a moment.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 97. The other players are quiet and don’t look at him. Harlan grabs some food that’s on a plate and throws it at Diego-

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fuck you! DIEGO is professional and doesn’t react.

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fuck you, you Mexican fuck! HARLAN doesn’t get far into his tirade before MOLLY quick steps in and defuses the situation.

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You undocumented fucking border jumping fuck!

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Hey HEY! (to HARLAN) You get out on the terrace.

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: (to Diego) You’ve been pullin’ that shit all night!

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (to Harlan) Out on the terrace. MOLLY motions to CASSIE, the relief dealer, the way a baseball manager would motion to the bullpen. MOLLY walks DIEGO away from the table--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (quietly) You good?

dialogues.speaker: DIEGO
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Have a drink. MOLLY goes out on to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --where Harlan’s waiting.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: What the hell.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy)

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: I'll apologize to Diego.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yeah and you’re gonna go home, I’m making a floor call, that’s it. HARLAN doesn’t say anything--he just stares out at Los Angeles...

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (pause) Did you hear me?

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: I don’t have it.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (beat) You don’t have what? HARLAN looks at MOLLY very simply...

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: A million-two, I don’t have it. MOLLY takes that in...

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (pause) Go home.

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: We’ll meet tomorrow and talk about what to do. (beat) And what you’ve gotta do is tell Sheila the truth, okay, you tell her the truth. Tell her what happened. And I’m gonna help you, I’m gonna get you to a meeting. We'll talk tomorrow and figure out what to do about the money.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Harlan and I didn’t meet the next day. He just called me and said everything was okay and showed up the next week with a check. 98.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 99.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOLLY’s standing in front of her car, a Mercedes converti in the middle of a slightly heated exchange with PLAYER X

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Where did he get the money from?

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER X
dialogues.text: I loaned it to him.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Loaned it?

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER X
dialogues.text: I get 50% of his wins until the debt’s paid off and then 50% for the next two years with no exposure.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You’re taking 50% of his wins and no exposure on the losses.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER X
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: First of all he’ll never climb out of that, that’s sharecropper math. Second, you can’t stake a player and play in the game at the same time.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER X
dialogues.text: I've been doing it for three years. MOLLY’s stunned...

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (pause) You've been staking Harlan?

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER X
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (beat) Jesus Christ--

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER X
dialogues.text: It’s not cheating.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: It is a hundred percent cheating.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 100.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER X
dialogues.text: Tell me how it’s cheating.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Are you kidding?

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER X
dialogues.text: Tell me how it’s cheating.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: If you have an interest in another player winning?

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER X
dialogues.text: You think I’m gonna take a dive? And if I did, who would care?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You fold your hole cards--a five of clubs and a jack of hearts--he’s still in the game. It would benefit him to know that the five of hearts and jack of spades are no longer in play, don’t you think?

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER X
dialogues.text: You think I’m signaling him?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I’m saying it can’t fuckin’ happen again.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER X
dialogues.text: (pause) You know who the biggest winner in this game is?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER X
dialogues.text: You know who the second biggest winner is?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Look--

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER X
dialogues.text: You.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: We’ve had this conversation a couple of times before.  MOLLY gets Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 101.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER X
dialogues.text: Maybe it’s time to have it again. ‘Cause between you, the dealers and the girls you’re taking a lot of money out of the game.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You made more money playing poker this year than you did making movies.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER X
dialogues.text: I think we should talk again about capping your tips.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You want to get together with the other players--who on my tax returns are called clients--and discuss putting a ceiling on my wages.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER X
dialogues.text: That’s right.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: It’ll be America’s most closely- watched anti-trust case.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER X
dialogues.text: Are you threatening me?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: That’s movie dialogue and you were threatening me. Here’s your check. I'll see you Tuesday. back into her car. PLAYER X comes over to the driver’s side to say one last thing...

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER X
dialogues.text: You're sleeping with him, right?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (pause) Harlan?

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER X
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I knew he meant Player Y.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER X
dialogues.text: Is he writing a song about you, are you his muse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 102.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I'll see you Tuesday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A game is underway and we see the hands of PLAYER X. We m down the table and see ANOTHER PAIR OF HANDS. They belong PLAYER Y.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I always found Player Y to be a nice guy. Polite, a good loser, a good winner, and unflappable in the face of boorishness.

dialogues.speaker: DERRICK
dialogues.text: Tell us who you’re fucking besides your famous girlfriend.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER Y
dialogues.text: No one, and can we maybe not talk like this in front of Molly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PLAYER Y is playing a few chords for MOLLY in his home st -a few gold records on the wall along with a bank of Gram and other awards.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I'd go to the Hollywood Hills home he shared with his girlfriend to drop off or pick up a check and sometimes he’d play me a little of whatever he was working on. Player Y's GIRLFRIEND steps in--she’s in the middle of dressing for a night out.

dialogues.speaker: GIRLFRIEND
dialogues.text: Excuse me. You gotta get dressed, we’re gonna be late. (to MOLLY) Is it Millie?

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER Y
dialogues.text: Molly.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Millie’s fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + te

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 103.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOLLY’s working out on a bike in the gym in her building. PHONE BUZZES and she checks the text.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: He started texting me--mostly game stuff but once in a while a joke or a compliment. INT. MOLLY’S APARTMENT/BEDROOM - NIGHT MOLLY’s sitting up in bed reading. Her phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: It was around lam on the night of the American Music Awards when my phone rang. She looks at the caller ID.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello?

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER Y
dialogues.text: (from the phone) Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: He was hammered.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Are you alright? (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER Y
dialogues.text: (from the phone) Are you home?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (into phone) I am.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER Y
dialogues.text: Where is your home?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (into phone) Listen, bud, you’re wasted. Can you get home?

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER Y
dialogues.text: (from the phone) I want to come over.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 104. MOLLY’s in a tough spot and needs to navigate this carefully...

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (pause) Do you think that’s a good idea?

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER Y
dialogues.text: I want to hang out with you outside that room with those idiots staring at you.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (pause) How were the AMA‘s?

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER Y
dialogues.text: A lot of fake people. Viners and YouTube stars. I sang like I was in the high school play.I’m having a low self-image moment. What are you wearing?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry?

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER Y
dialogues.text: I want to tell you something.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (beat) Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER Y
dialogues.text: No, I want to whisper it in your ear.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Listen--

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER Y
dialogues.text: It’s not a bad idea. It’s not, I’ve thought about it. You broke up with your boyfriend and I went alone tonight so what does that say about the state of my, uh, you know... I think about you all the time. You are so cool. And nice. I’m in a car right now, I want to come over.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (beat) You're not driving the car, right?

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER Y
dialogues.text: Where do you live?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 105.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Okay, listen to me. You’re drunk and I’m not so I’m gonna be team captain, okay? I want you to hang up the phone and think about this for 30 minutes. Drink a lot of water, get some air and think about this for 30 minutes. If you’re still sure it’s a good idea in 30 minutes, call me back.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER Y
dialogues.text: (from the phone) I think--No, I know I’m falling in-- MOLLY hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: He didn’t call back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The players are doing their pre-game mingling.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: At the game Tuesday night he was sheepish and said--

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER Y
dialogues.text: (whispering) I passed out. Thank you, you’re a class act.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (whispering) Don’t worry about it.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER Y
dialogues.text: (whispering) I’m writing you an email.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (whispering) You don’t have to do that.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER Y
dialogues.text: (whispering) It’s in draft. When I get it right I’ll hit send.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 106.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s late at night and MOLLY’s driving along Sunset.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I assumed the email was going to be an apology which really wasn’t necessary--that he was embarrassed, that kind of thing. Her PHONE BUZZES on the passenger seat and she answers.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: It turned out it was an invitation to go with him to Cabo San Lucas. EXT. MOLLY’S CAR - SAME TIME We’re on the outside of the car now.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER Y, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I’ve only ever had one fantasy. I’m sitting on a plane and a beautiful woman sits down next to me. I’m messengering you a ticket to Cabo. Leaves Friday, returns Sunday. Your seat is 1-B. I'll be in 1-A. And then Molly's car SCREECHES to the side of the road, almost fishtailing.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: It wasn’t until I was finished reading that I saw that the email wasn’t from Player Y. It was from his girlfriend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOLLY’s sitting there breathing, trying to think. Her cel starts ringing in her hand...

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: His girlfriend had gone into his account and found the letter in drafts. And she sent it to me. And she sent it to the wives and girlfriends of everyone who played in the game. And I knew the truth even before I answered the call that came next. MOLLY finally answers the phone--  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 107.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER X
dialogues.text: (over phone) You are so fucked. MOLLY takes a beat and snaps the phone closed. Then she g out of her car, which is on the side of the street, and l against it with the occasional car passing by.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: You didn’t have to be a strategic mastermind to know what was coming next. The musician and his girlfriend stayed together on the condition that he not play in my game and that was all Player xX needed to get the other guys to fire me. I’d made a dumb joke about an anti-trust suit and I never ran another game in LA. We stay on MOLLY for a long moment, watching her from a l way down the street, her silhouette leaning against the c

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. CHARLIE’S OFFICE - DAY MOLLY and CHARLIE have been at it for a while.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: There’s no such word as verticality.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Verticality?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: In the book, on page 217. When you lose the game in LA and come to New York you admire the city’s verticality.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: It’s a word.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I don’t think so. Once you’re in New York you talk about games that lasted all night, two nights, being up for days but you don’t mention drugs.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: There were drugs. I’m two years clean. Oe OF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 108.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You left the drugs out of the book.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You know what, I’m not paying $250,000 for your Amazon customer review.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Well so far you’re not paying me anything.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I just emailed you verticality from Merriam-Webster’s Dictionary.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What’s an advance on a book like this?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: The advance?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (pause) It depends. INT. AGENT’S OFFICE - DAY MOLLY’s talking to her agent, LOIS.

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: If you guarantee the publishers certain elements--if you’re able to guarantee that--then I can get you a million and a half which you'd probably double in sales plus ancillary rights.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: What kinds of elements?

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: Well you know what kind.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Lois--  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 109.

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: You have to use real names. You have to name the bold-faced names. You have to tell tales and those tales have to be compelling and that’s just the way it is. (pause) There’s a guy who sits outside my Starbucks with a cardboard sign that says, “Vietnam Vet” and every morning I give him a quarter and right now the only difference between you and him is that you have a story.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I’m one-thousand percent sure that the homeless Vietnam vet has a better one.

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: You have one asset. Write your story and I can get you a million and a half and that’s the floor. Write about a girl from Loveland who gets rich and then loses everything in a civil forfeiture and no one--listen to me--no one will care. Not the publishers and not the readers.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (pause) It’s none of my business but you should really give that guy more than a quarter.

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: Millions or nothing. Go big or go home and live with your mother. For the rest of your life. This is excruciating for MOLLY...

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (pause) What if I...What if you told the publishers that I’1l name the players who were already named in the Brad Marion deposition?

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: All four? He OK Oe OF ee OK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 110.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: The ones that were already--I’1l use the real names of the players who were already named by Bad Brad, what if I did that?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: They’re gonna want to know what stories you’re willing to tell. You spent 8 years in Hollywood and 2 years in New York running the world’s most exclusive, glamorous and decadent man cave. So what do the publishers get from you about people with real names? MOLLY takes a long time before...

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (long pause) One of them was a bad tipper. I’1l say which one. MOLLY and LOIS sit there for a moment as LOIS taps her pe lightly on her desk and we

dialogues.speaker: CUT BACK TO
dialogues.text: INT. CHARLIE’S OFFICE - DAY

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: My advance was thirty-five thousand dollars.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: How did you meet the Playmates?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I'd met them a few years earlier on a G-5 to Vegas.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: How did you have occasion to be on a private jet to Vegas with Playboy Playmates?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I was the CEO of Douchebag Inc., I often had occasion to be on private jets to Vegas with Playboy Playmates. What’s our plan? ee OK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 111.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: The first thing I’m gonna do is get you a minor role reduction, get the 12 points knocked down to 10.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: What’s a minor role reduction?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I’m gonna argue to the prosecutor that you didn’t play a leadership role. That you were an employee who was hired and fired by the players.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Not a chance.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I think we’ve got a good chance.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: No, there’s not a chance I’m gonna let you make that argument.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: It’s not true.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Let me explain how the point system works.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I know how it works. Points correspond to the prosecutor's sentencing recommendation. You try to get point reductions based on a variety of factors including, say, prior criminal history, which I don’t have, or whether the defendant played a minor role, which I certainly did not.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You really think this is a good time to hog credit?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I built it from scratch.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: There was already a game at the Viper Room when you came along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 112.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: The LA game was legal, I wasn’t taking a rake. I’m talking about the New York game which I built and scaled from scratch. I wasn’t fireable from the New York game, I made sure of that, so...no.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I wasn’t really listening.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I’m refusing you permission to seek a minor role reduction. I’m refusing you permission to invalidate my entire career.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I’m not caring.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Charlie--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Do you want kids? Are you interested in having a family?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I don’t get some point reductions and the sentencing recommendation guidelines say 8 to 12 years, Molly. That’s before they try to jam you up more with money laundering.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Money--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: The moment you changed the Russians’ money for chips.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I'd have to be aware that--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Find me twelve men and women who'll believe you weren’t aware of exactly who was sitting at your table and where their money came from. (pause) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 113.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So that’s that. You were a cocktail waitress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOLLY’s right where we left her, leaning against her car.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: When I lost the LA game I told myself it was no big deal. It was just supposed to be an adventure and a way to meet influential people. And I'd saved over two- hundred thousand dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOLLY’s sitting at her kitchen table, wearing the sweatsh and Denver Broncos cap we saw her in earlier. She’s liste to her iPod and staring into space. She’s depressed and w watch the depression turn into anger and then action.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But that was just a weak firewall I'd hastily built to keep out the humiliation and depression I knew was coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOLLY’s at the end of the bar drinking alone.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It had to end sometime, I just thought it would be on my time. I didn’t think it was gonna be taken away from me. And for such a stomach-turning reason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOLLY’s working out in the otherwise deserted gym in her apartment building but this is an angry work-out--the car equivalent of revenge sex.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 114.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I made the real housewives of the Chateau Marmont uncomfortable because I unambiguously rejected passes from their degenerate husbands and boyfriends? Thanks ladies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s raining and MOLLY’s cutting through the rain, joggin a path with her athlete’s body beating the incline and ag this no fun-run.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: And thanks fellas. You trusted me for eight years and I proved worthy of that trust, over and over, and none of you could speak up? MOLLY hits another gear and disappears around a curve in path as we --
