dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOLLY’s sitting on her windowsill with the window open an smoking a joint.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The game had given me an identity, respect, and a defined place ina world that was inaccessible and in one irrational heartbeat it was taken away. I was irrelevant and forgotten overnight. INT. THERAPIST’S WAITING ROOM - DAY It’s a small privacy room. MOLLY comes in, sees the butto she’s supposed to press to announce her arrival and pushe it.  115.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: It'd been two weeks since I lost the game and I made an appointment to see someone because now the humiliation and depression had given way to a blinding anger at my powerlessness over the unfair whims of men who had leverage over me and I wanted to talk it out with someone. MOLLY picks up a magazine and starts thumbing through it.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: That was it, that’s what was making me angry. It was that there weren’t any rules. These power moves weren’t framed by right and wrong, just ego and vanity. She puts the magazine back and picks up a different one.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Selfish whims with no regard to consequence. No fairness, no justice. And that giggling, cackling call from Player X--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scene we saw earlier--

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER X, (OVER THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: You are so fucked.

dialogues.speaker: CUT BACK TO
dialogues.text: INT. THERAPIST’S WAITING ROOM - DAY

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I couldn’t lose to that green- screened little shit and I didn’t want a therapist to make me feel okay about it. You know what makes you feel okay about losing? Winning. MOLLY tosses the magazine back, grabs her bag, turns the arrival light switch back off and heads out the door.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 116.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I got on a plane to New York.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the famous landmark in all its beauty and then we BACK to see MOLLY heading into the hotel. *

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Wall Street, Madison Avenue, Fifth Avenue, Sutton Place, the Dakota, the Beresford, the San Remo--the players were here, I just had to bait the hook. This time I didn’t have movie stars.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This time I used Playboy Playmates. * A beautiful Playmate named JESSE is sitting at the bar. S waiting for someone and checking the front door when MOLL sits down on the other side of her and taps her shoulder. They give each other a hug.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And these weren’t just any Playmates. They had particular skill sets. Jesse was Puerto Rican knockout who grew up working in card rooms and was a good player herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOLLY, JESSE and two other Playmates--SHELBY and WINSTON, sitting at a table with a “reserved” sign on it. Their sp drinks are being replaced with a new round. *

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I could stake her, infiltrate other games and poach their big ticket players. She could glance at a table and tell you how much money was on it. MOLLY holds a plastic sandwich bag filled with different colored poker chips, takes out a fist-full of chips and throws them on the table.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 117.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Six-hundred and forty-thousand, eight-hundred dollars.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Not even close.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: No, that’s how much is left in the bag. MOLLY smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHELBY is tapping away at a laptop--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Shelby could write code and was a decent hacker. Right now I’ve asked her to tell me my account balance at B of A.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (to SHELBY) You got it yet or are you playing Minecraft?

dialogues.speaker: SHELBY
dialogues.text: Playing Minecraft.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Shelby--

dialogues.speaker: SHELBY
dialogues.text: You don’t have an account at B of A. Here’s your balance at CitiBank. SHELBY turns her laptop around to show MOLLY. MOLLY’s pleased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WINSTON’s writing on a napkin with a Sharpie. She’s writi in Farsi and her penmanship is beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Winston would be working for the CIA if she could pass a drug test. She was the daughter of an American diplomat who’s lived in nine different countries and who had the email addresses of half the Saudi royal family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: eK  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 118.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (to WINSTON) Who’s the biggest game in Manhattan and what are the stakes?

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: On any given night it’s either Eddie Ting or Irv Gotti. 50K buy- in, blinds are one-thousand/two- thousand.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: But that’s Manhattan.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (beat) * What do you mean? *

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: The biggest game in New York is in * Brooklyn. Russian Jews. Buy-in’s a * hundred K. No one runs the game, * they just play and pay.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I didn’t know that.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: That’s what you have me for.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Tomorrow night we start recruiting. *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s high-end decadence. Crowded with beautiful people an pulsing with house music. MOLLY, JESSE, SHELBY and WINSTO all dressed for the job--sexy but not slutty--are standin the balcony that wraps around the club so they can get a bird's-eye view of the floor.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: We couldn’t promise anyone they’d rub elbows with movie stars, but New York has one thing Hollywood doesn’t. The Yankees. And there was one Yankee in particular that every man in America would line up to lose to.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 119.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You don’t say his name out loud. Write it on a cocktail napkin, then crumple the napkin up and put it in a glass of water so they can see the ink dissolve.

dialogues.speaker: SHELBY
dialogues.text: That’s really necessary?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: It’s not at all necessary.

dialogues.speaker: SHELBY
dialogues.text: Got it.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Can we tell them when the game’s gonna start?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You tell them it’s been happening once a week for about six months at a location you won’t disclose right now. There’s a pretty long waiting list for a chair but Molly’s here somewhere tonight, I'll introduce you.

dialogues.speaker: SHELBY
dialogues.text: Do we mention the stakes?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: They'll ask you.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: 50K buy-in, blinds are one and two? And now Molly stares down at something...nothing...she’s thinking...

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (pause) Mol?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (pause) Two-hundred and fifty.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Blinds are two-fifty and five?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: No, the buy-in. Two-hundred and fifty-thousand dollars.  120.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: That’s gonna make a lot of noise.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Just enough to be heard on Rodeo Drive. Guys? You’re up. MOLLY downs her glass of scotch and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men have now descended on their table. JESSE writes a nam a cocktail napkin and shows it to the guy she’s been talk to. We see the guy mouth “Seriously?” and JESSE nods befo she drowns the cocktail napkin in her drink. We see MOLLY watching this from a distance.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We went to clubs, polo matches in the Hamptons, art gallery openings--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOLLY’s looking at a painting while SHELBY talks to a TRU FUND KID.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: They never approached anyone, the men came to them.

dialogues.speaker: SHELBY
dialogues.text: I don’t think you'd be interested. The buy-in’s 250K and half the players re-load after two hands.

dialogues.speaker: TRUST FUND KID
dialogues.text: Two-hundred and fifty thousand is steep. That’s almost what I paid for my second car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WINSTON is having a drink and a quiet conversation with a at the bar. MOLLY’s farther down the bar watching the new the TV.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: And they never asked anyone to play. The game had to be an impossible ticket. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 121.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It had to be clandestine and sexy but above all, it had to be exclusive. What these men want is to want. They had to ask us.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: (to the man) You should talk to my friend Molly.

dialogues.speaker: SHELBY
dialogues.text: (to the older man) I can introduce you to Molly.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: (introducing them) Molly, this is David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A magnificent suite with breathtaking views of the city. The Shuffle Master rips through a deck. A full game is underway with the playmates working the bar and as server uniformed masseuse is working on someone’s shoulders. MOL observing the action.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It only took seven weeks of recruiting to get ten players and there were four on a waiting list and these circles that was more than enough to start the mythology. By morning, gamblers would be hearing and telling stories about this game in London, Tokyo and Dubai. At the end of that year I reported an income of four-million, seven-hundred and seventy-three thousand dollars. Every square inch of it legal and on the books. I still hadn’t taken a rake. And I still hadn’t accidentally recruited members of a Russian crime syndicate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 122.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on an Aderall pill being crushed with a mortar and pestle. We PULL BACK and see it’s MOLLY.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: In the beginning I was using drugs to stay awake. First aderall. Then Aderall crushed up to defeat the time release. We go through a SERIES OF SHOTS showing MOLLY and the PLAYMATES getting ready for a game. --SHELBY, JESSE, and WINSTON are in various states of dre and having fun trying on different outfits drinking champagne, doing lines of coke, etc.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Then coke, valium, vicodin, percocet and more aderall. INT. MOLLY’S APARTMENT - DAY A luxury rental with a poker table in the living room. Fo flat screen tv’s are being bolted to the walls.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I rented a penthouse apartment and installed plasma screens for the sports betters. I had the lower stakes games on Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Sundays at my place with Tuesday night at the Plaza being the big game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --A bottle of champagne is opened and poured. A glass is down next to MOLLY, who’s at the desk with her laptop ope We see quick shards of information on her screen--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: My spreadsheets would tell me who was playing tonight, what their track record was, where I had to cut off their credit, everything down to their kids’ birthdays. --Candles are being lit and placed around the room. A tab clock gets put out of sight. An iPod gets popped into a d

dialogues.speaker: HH HK
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 123.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Casinos have discovered that certain scents make people more likely to place big bets. The casinos pump those scents in through the ventilation. I had custom candles made. --A poker table gets stood up by two dealers--one male, o female. Twenty brand new decks of cards with Molly’s init get stacked on the table. Bellmen are bringing in stools.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: At 7:00 the dealers came and the table was set up and polished and eleven stools were placed around it exactly twelve inches apart. --A case of chips is opened and stacks counted. The chips beautiful and heavy and engraved with Molly’s initials. * Included among the chips are rectangular gold plates that “MB” but have no denomination. *

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I used custom chips and two dealers who worked an hour on, an hour off with a new crew coming in after twelve hours. * --The female dealer, a tall knockout, fans a deck out in front of her and sweeps it up with one card. She repeats as well as a few other simple tricks that show how fast a nimble her hands are.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I'd been working with a new dealer named Small, that was her name, and Small was 5-11. She’d been working in trashy card rooms on the east side and we became friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOLLY’s writing checks and putting them into envelopes an SMALL is sitting up in the bed with her shoes kicked off.

dialogues.speaker: SMALL
dialogues.text: You've gotta do it. Not doing it is * insanity. You must be able to see * that now. *

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Small had been suggesting it for a * long time and she was suggesting it again because of an incident the * week before. *  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 124. PRE-LAP a DOORBELL--

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. MOLLY’S APARTMENT - DAY MOLLY, in jeans and a t-shirt, answers her door. COLE, th trust fund kid we saw earlier, is standing there.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Hey Cole.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Come on in.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Thanks. You’ve got my check?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (picking up an envelope) I do, right here.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Hey, can I show you something on

dialogues.speaker: KEN
dialogues.text: Is it Michigan/Michigan State? I took State and the points. MOLLY clicks her TV on with the remote. The TV’s showing quad split of tape from four security cameras trained on poker game.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: This is last Tuesday night’s game.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Shit. Molly. If the guys find out you’ve got cameras on them--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (pointing) This is you in the seventh chair. Look at your stack of chips.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 125.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Look at the time stamp--1:06am. Let’s fast forward to 1:07.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Come on, Cole. 1:07 you lose the hand to Boosty. 1:08. (she fast forwards to 1:08) Our sheets say you didn’t buy in again between 1:06 and 1:08 but look at that--your stack got bigger.

dialogues.speaker: KEN
dialogues.text: Molly--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: So let’s rewind. This screen's got the dealer changeover while at the same time back on this screen... aaaaaand--there we are. We PUSH IN on the TV and see COLE drop his hand below the table--presumably into his jacket pocket--take out a cigarette and casually drop some chips in front of himsel like he’d been playing with the chips all along.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And that’s why I can’t reconcile seventeen-thousand dollars from Tuesday’s game. (pause) A 7-11's got security cameras on their Slushy machine, I’ve got a million dollars changing hands every two minutes, imbecile, you didn’t think I had eyes on the table? COLE starts breathing heavily--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shh--relax.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: I owe people money.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I know, so why isn’t it coming out of the trust fund.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 126.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: I'd need my parents’ permission and they’d kill me. You don’t even understand--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Alright. Look, first of all, those guys who make the counterfeit chips, they’re taking you for a ride. They know there are signatures built into the chips-- exact weight, infra-red markings-- * breathe. Second, don’t try this at someone else’s game because they’re gonna express their anger in a much different way than I am. I'll cover you, You owe me 17-thousand dollars * and when I get it I’ll give you the tape. That’s it.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: So when Tuesday night came, Small was at it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the open door we can see the suite being prepared the game.

dialogues.speaker: SMALL
dialogues.text: Your exposure’s crazy, Molly. It’s not if, it’s when. You’re gonna get stiffed and your risk is nuts.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: It was 17-thousand dollars.

dialogues.speaker: SMALL
dialogues.text: This time. You told me what happened with Harlan Eustice.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: He paid.

dialogues.speaker: SMALL
dialogues.text: That time.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: If I took a rake this game would no longer be legal.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 127.

dialogues.speaker: SMALL
dialogues.text: And if you can’t cover a debt this game will no longer exist. You’re the bank now, you’re guaranteeing the game. MOLLY doesn’t say anything...

dialogues.speaker: SMALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (sitting up) Alright. But if you see a hand you don’t want to carry, just look at me, flash me a number and I’1l1 take that number off the table. Most runners cap it at 5 percent. I'll see you out there.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: See you out there. SMALL goes back out into the main room and MOLLY starts filling in another check. She stops, thinks, takes a coup of pills, chews them up and washes the bad taste down wit champagne as we --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hand is underway with SMALL dealing. MOLLY watches from short distance as the pot gets bigger and bigger.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Around 2am there was a pot that was up to a million and a half pre-flop with five players still in. SMALL burns a card and lays out the flop.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: My hope was that the flop would chase four of them off.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER
dialogues.text: A hundred-thousand.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER
dialogues.text: Call.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER
dialogues.text: Call and raise a hundred-thousand.

dialogues.speaker: SMALL
dialogues.text: Two-hundred thousand to you.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 128.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER
dialogues.text: Plus two-hundred.

dialogues.speaker: SMALL
dialogues.text: (to Player #1) Three-hundred thousand to you.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER
dialogues.text: Call.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: There was now two-point four million on the table.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER
dialogues.text: Call.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Two-point six million.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER
dialogues.text: Call.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER
dialogues.text: Call.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Three million. SMALL burns another card and lays out the turn. MOLLY’s thinking.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She was right, I was extending credit, big numbers. And it’s not like Harlan Eustice hadn’t already put the fear of God into me. If I couldn’t pay, one time, that’d be the end of the game. I was the house. She catches SMALL’s eye and holds up two fingers while mouthing “Two”. SMALL’s quick hands begin to stack the chips in the pot, knocking two percent off one of the stacks, tapping those chips on the table so the players know she’s doing it and sliding the chips to the side.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: That’s how quickly I’d made the decision. And just as quickly, Small calculated two percent of the pot and took it off the table. That was it. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 129.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I'd just taken a rake, in violation of U.S. Criminal Code 1955.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the remnants of a game that ended a short while ag MOLLY’s at work on the books with a drink at her side. On the players has stayed behind--late 30’s and drunk. He do a drink and then pours himself another.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: It’s time to introduce Douglas Downey ‘cause Downey’s gonna take us all the way home. Downey was a drunk and he’d stay after the game and hang out while I did the books. DOWNEY brings his newly poured drink over to MOLLY’s area takes a seat.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He was hard to understand when he was drunk and his conversation openers would always sound like the title of a detective novel.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNEY
dialogues.text: (he sighs--then) Victim of circumstance.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNEY
dialogues.text: Story of, uh, you know, story of my proverbial, you know, life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOWNEY again brings a drink over to MOLLY who’s doing the books and barely pretending to pay attention--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He’d talk about his marriage.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNEY
dialogues.text: I married young, Mol. I married young and I married dull.  130.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After the game--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: He talked about wanting a better life.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNEY
dialogues.text: If I’d been born in Greenwich instead of Flushing? New Canaan, Fifth Avenue? Gone to Rye Country Day? Princeton? The life I’d have? The wife I’d have? I'd be a plaaaaayuh. Victim of circumstances. Mol, these are things I only say to you.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Good call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After the game--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And he’d talk about another game he played in. It was the Brooklyn game. The Brighton Beach game where they played all night and all day. The game that was populated by Russians.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNEY
dialogues.text: I’m the only Irish guy they let play. These are the nicest guys I’ve ever met, Mol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After the game--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Then one night Douglas Downey lost eighty-thousand at my game and didn’t have it.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNEY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. You’re so, you know, just, nice. And you’re honest and I respect your hustle so I just want to be straight with you. It’s been a bad month. You know, God, sports. Some investments went bad.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 131.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You won a hundred and ninety last week.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNEY
dialogues.text: I owe Eddie and Irv.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Got it.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNEY
dialogues.text: You know what? No. Fuck Eddie, fuck Irv, I’m paying you!

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Doug--

dialogues.speaker: DOWNEY
dialogues.text: I’m paying you, Mol!

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Quiet down, listen to me--

dialogues.speaker: DOWNEY
dialogues.text: The little guy’s gonna win for once!

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I don’t even know what that means but you can’t stiff Eddie Ting or Irv Gotti.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNEY
dialogues.text: I’m not afraid of those guys.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You really should be.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNEY
dialogues.text: Mol--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: There’s another way.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNEY
dialogues.text: I’m a winner trapped inside the body of--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Douglas.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNEY
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy)

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: The Brooklyn game. Is everything I’ve heard true?

dialogues.speaker: DOWNEY
dialogues.text: About Brighton Beach?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNEY
dialogues.text: What have you heard?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: That the Russians have deep pockets, are bad at poker, give action and pay instantly. Bring me some of those players and I’1ll give you a piece of the game until your 80K’s paid down.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNEY
dialogues.text: I’m the only Irish guy they let play.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Did you understand what I said?

dialogues.speaker: DOWNEY
dialogues.text: No, I’m saying this because you’re Irish and they may not want to play in your game. I’m the only Irish guy they let play.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I’m not Irish.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNEY
dialogues.text: You’re not?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNEY
dialogues.text: Molly Bloom?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You're thinking of the James Joyce character--

dialogues.speaker: DOWNEY
dialogues.text: I always thought you were Irish. 132. ee OK  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 133.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I’m not. Can you get me some of those players?

dialogues.speaker: DOWNEY
dialogues.text: Isn't there a famous book--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Doug. Focus up. Yes, there is a book by James Joyce called Ulysses that has a character named Molly Bloom and that is why you think I’m Irish and now it’s time to get past that. Can you get me some Brighton Beach players?

dialogues.speaker: DOWNEY
dialogues.text: If you’re not Irish what are you?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I’m a Russian Jew.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The next week I had some new players.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is sparkling and set for a new game. The doorbel rings and JESSE answers the door. A handsome man in his e 30's wearing a coat and tie is standing there.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Mike was the first one to arrive.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Good evening.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Good evening, I’m Mike Druzhinsky. I’m here to see Molly.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Mike owned a chain of medical clinics and had already posted with a wire transfer.

dialogues.speaker: HOTEL SUITE
dialogues.text: ILLYA and ALEX GERSHEN, 22 and 24, are standing at Molly’ desk. ALEX hands MOLLY a backpack. MOLLY opens it and see what’s inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oe OF ee OK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 134.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Next were the Gershen brothers, Illya and Alex. They were in the business of exporting steel to China. Alex brought a quarter of a million dollars in cash ina backpack.

dialogues.speaker: HOTEL SUITE
dialogues.text: HELLY HABIB, 30’s and a cherubic mess, stands in front of MOLLY with a painting wrapped in brown paper.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: And then Helly Habib. The Habib family owns the largest collection of classical art in the world, valued at 3-billion dollars, and Helly runs the Habib gallery on Madison Avenue.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’ll need you to post the first few times, I hope you understand. (handing him a card) Here’s information about wiring the post in advance.

dialogues.speaker: HELLY
dialogues.text: Thank you. HELLY starts unwrapping the painting he brought-- HELLY (CONT’D) As for tonight, I was not able to put my hands on cash today because I woke up this morning after the banks had closed so I’m hoping you'll accept this as temporary collateral. MOLLY stares at the painting blank-faced...

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (pause--calmy) That is...an authentic Monet?

dialogues.speaker: HELLY
dialogues.text: Grabbed it right off the wall.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (pause) You came over here carrying a Monet.

dialogues.speaker: HH HH HK
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy)

dialogues.speaker: HELLY
dialogues.text: I was driven. And I have security outside the door.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Okay. Helly, here’s what I need you to do. I need you to get this, what, 20--?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: --27-million dollar painting out of here right now. And your, I assume, armed security--?

dialogues.speaker: HELLY
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: --can’t stand in front of the door. Fix that up, come on back and I’1l extend you credit tonight up to one and a half.
Bets fly into the pot as SMALL’s magician hands quickly s chips in piles, pull off two percent, tap the chips on th table and throws them into a rake bucket.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Mike, Illya, Alex and Helly. Those were the players Douglas Downey brought me. As advertised, they played loose, gave action, lost to the regulars and settled right away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SMALL deals another card and the whole table reacts as MO looks on.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: People have asked, “Wasn’t there any way to tell that the new players were connected to one of the darkest, deadliest and far- reaching organized crime syndicates in the world?” No. There wasn’t.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNEY
dialogues.text: All in.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 136. INT. CHARLIE’S OFFICE - EVENING MOLLY’s sitting in the office and waiting as CHARLIE come wearing a coat.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I wish I had better news.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Harrison Wellstone didn’t go for the minor role reduction?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: He didn’t buy that I was a cocktail waitress?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Aww. (claps him on the shoulder) Was it because I wasn’t?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Hey, I tried. That’s what you’re not paying me to do.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: So what now? CHARLIE looks at MOLLY--he knows this is going to be a difficult subject.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: The Government is expressing an interest in you as a cooperating witness.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You don’t say.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Molly--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Who could’ve possibly seen that coming?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Let’s have the conversation. in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy)

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: It’s gonna be very short because I don’t know anything at all that can help them.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You don’t know anything that can help them convict the Russians but you know things that can help them.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Did you know that 97 percent of federal cases never go to trial? Even though your chance of being convicted at trial is a little more than one in a hundred?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: If you want to go to trial that’s fine but it’s gonna cost in the area of three and a half million dollars.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Which the Justice Department knows I don’t have because they took all my money in a civil forfeiture which they can do without a warrant because your property doesn’t have a presumption of innocence. Then after I was arrested by 17 agents holding automatic weapons--totally necessary and not at all meant to intimidate me--they gave me two days to hire a lawyer and appear in a courtroom on the other side of the country.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: If you’re saying that everything that happens in a federal bust from the moment you’re arrested is designed to persuade you to plead guilty, you’re correct.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: So tell me all the ways I can help ‘cause I really feel I owe it to them. Speaking of owing, the IRS has put a tax lien on the money they took from me.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (beat) None of that-- 137.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 138.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Taking my money wasn’t a tax, they also need me to give them my money. * Or they’1ll take it again.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Good to get that off your chest?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: It needed to be said.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Not really. So to be clear, you're not interested in entering into a cooperation agreement with the prosectors.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: That’s right.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Because you feel the Government has acted--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: --like the neighborhood extortionist? No. The U.S. Attorney's Office does everything within the law to fight crime and also for some reason to keep taking my stuff, I get it. And if I had testimony that could lead to the conviction of a bad guy no one would have to coerce me into cooperating. But I don’t. I have dirt. I have dish. I have gossip. So my value to the prosecution is exactly the same as it is to Hollywood. I’m here to ensure the New York Post covers the trial. I’m here to sell tickets.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Which is nonetheless value to the prosecution so what we do is leverage it to get you a favorable sentencing recommendation or, better yet, complete immunity. * There’s a KNOCK on the door-- * CHARLIE (CONT’D) * (shouting) * Come in! * It’s STELLA, Charlie’s daughter whom we met earlier. *  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 139. CHARLIE (CONT’D) Oh hey honey.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Hey Stella.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: What does he have you doing now? STELLA’s getting an essay out of her backpack and giving to her father.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: An essay on three poems with a common theme.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Two paragraphs.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Which three poems?

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: “Close”, “Rush” and “Walls”.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I know those. What’s the common theme?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (while reading) Things with one-word titles.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (to CHARLIE) Are you sure you’re qualified to be-

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (still reading) Hang on. And yes.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (to STELLA) Anytime you want to run away from home you can come live with me.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: And then when you discover she doesn’t have a home you can come back to me. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ce ee a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ee eK ee OK  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 140.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to STELLA) Good job. Why don’t you get a snack and start your homework in one of the conference rooms.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: Okay. (to MOLLY) See you.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: There’s no law that says you can’t just hit him in the head.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: There is a law that says that, it’s the first thing I taught her to read. (to STELLA) Go. STELLA exits.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: My father used to give us extra work.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Where is your father in all this?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (beat) He’s--you mean physically?--He’s in Colorado.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Are your parents still together?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Are you and your father close?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (pause) No.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Was he hard on you? ee OK ee Oe Oe OF Ht HF He OF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 141.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (smiles) You know how many girls at the Olympics have demanding fathers?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: All of them?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: That’s right. (pause) I was hard on him.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Mmmmmm...I was brat. INT. GIRL’S HOUSE/FOYER - DAY The GIRL, now 22, walks in the front door of her house. S got a USA Skiing jacket on and her skis over her shoulder She closes the door behind her. INT. CHARLIE’S OFFICE - DAY

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Fathers don’t care.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I'd start fights with him.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Why? INT. GIRL’S HOUSE/FOYER - DAY The GIRL hears her MOTHER shouting upstairs. INT. GIRL’S HOUSE/MASTER BEDROOM The MOTHER is on the phone shouting.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: (into phone) I put you through medical school, I raised the kids, I did every--and all you did was cheat on me. All you did was cheat. He

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He OK  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 142. We see MOLLY standing in the doorway hearing this, unseen her MOTHER. * INT. CHARLIE’S OFFICE - DAY *

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I don’t know. * (pause) * For the record, the law--1955--that * I’m accused of breaking, defines gambling as betting on games of chance.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Poker isn’t a game of chance. Roulette’s a game of chance. Poker’s a game of skill.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Molly--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Charlie, I'll tell them anything * they want to know about me. About me. That’s it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front door is open but we can’t yet see what’s happen

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Now stick a pin in the Russians for minute because remember Bad Brad * Marion? It turns out his 300- million dollar hedge fund wasn’t what you'd call...real.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now we see several men in suits escorting BRAD, who’s handcuffs, to a waiting black sedan that’s backed up by a Malibu patrol car.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: It was a Ponzi scheme. He'd been falsely reporting profits for years. He wasn’t even registered with the SEC. We see QUICK FLASHES of what Molly describes--  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy)

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: With the money given to him by friends and family he bought several Malibu beach houses, an airplane hangar full of cars, another one with an airplane, and the life he wanted. When he was arrested he had seventy-four hundred dollars in the bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a door shuts with a bang. BRAD is sitting at a table w his lawyers opposite several men and women from the government. Video cameras are pointed at him and a stenographer is recording his confession. BRAD’s gesticulating wildly and telling them everything.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Brad cooperated with the FBI and gave them hours of testimony on a range of subjects, including how three years earlier he’d lost 5.2- million dollars in an underground celebrity poker game that was run by a girl named Molly Bloom. His story was that I’d induced him to play in a high stakes game-- QUICK FLASHBACK to a scene we saw earlier--

dialogues.speaker: NEAL
dialogues.text: I just wanted to introduce you to Brad Marion, he wants to play.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And that due to my enabling he’d become a gambling addict. QUICK FLASHBACK to another scene we saw earlier--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A game is underway--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Brad, this game may not be for you.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 144.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOLLY and her lawyer, BUTTERMAN, are sitting across from three lawyers in a deposition.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Federal bankruptcy lawyers were brought in to recover as much of the boosted money as they could. I was sent a subpoena and flew out to L.A. to be deposed. Sitting next to me was my attorney at the time, Louis Butterman.

dialogues.speaker: BUTTERMAN
dialogues.text: My name’s Louis. You’ve been calling me Lou for two hours.

dialogues.speaker: BANKRUPTCY LAWYER
dialogues.text: I apologize, I thought it was Lou. (to MOLLY) Can you confirm the names on the list? This is Tab 27. Can you confirm that these people--let me ask this again so it’s clean on the record--can you confirm that the people listed here--Tab 27--all played poker with Brad Marion?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: The names on this list were provided to you by Brad Marion?

dialogues.speaker: BANKRUPTCY LAWYER
dialogues.text: I just need you to confirm for the record that your game included but was not limited to the players on this list.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I understand. What I’m trying to get in the record is that I’m not the one who provided the list.

dialogues.speaker: BANKRUPTCY LAWYER
dialogues.text: These names were provided by Brad Marion. So under oath--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yes, I can confirm the list is accurate.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: Oe OF

dialogues.speaker: OF
dialogues.text: ee OK ee OK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 145.

dialogues.speaker: BANKRUPTCY LAWYER
dialogues.text: On how many occasions did you invite Mr. Marion to play in the game?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Mr. Marion asked to be in the game. *

dialogues.speaker: BANKRUPTCY LAWYER
dialogues.text: That wasn’t my question.

dialogues.speaker: BUTTERMAN
dialogues.text: That wasn’t his question.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (to Butterman) Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: BANKRUPTCY LAWYER
dialogues.text: On how many occasions did you invite--

dialogues.speaker: BANKRUPTCY LAWYER
dialogues.text: And Donnie Silverman won the World Poker Championship?

dialogues.speaker: BUTTERMAN
dialogues.text: I’m gonna object on relevancy.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes. Donnie Silverman won the--

dialogues.speaker: BUTTERMAN
dialogues.text: He’s withdrawing the question.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: It’s public record, it was on television. Donnie Silverman won the World Poker Championship. They continue MOS--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Right there I mis-spoke. It’s not * called the World Poker Championship, it’s called the World Series of Poker. I was ordered to pay five-hundred thousand dollars in restitution-- *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 146.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lawyer walks a photograph over to a wall--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: --and somewhere in an FBI field office in New York, someone was pinning my picture to a wall. The lawyer pins Molly’s picture up. We PULL BACK and see wall is covered with pictures and lines that form an organizational chart--including Michael “Miko” Druzhinsky “Russian Alex” Gershen, Illya “The Son” Gershen and Helly Habib.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A game is underway.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: By this point I was running six games a week, sometimes at two different locations in a night. MOLLY downs a couple of pills with a glass of champagne.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: And by this point I was addicted to drugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a series of tight shots of pills being swallowed, being exchanged for two bottles of pills, bourbon being poured, a leather folding case with a small mirror, metal straw and razor blade, etc.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Adderall, Ambien, Xanax, coke, alcohol, Valium, Ativan, Trazadone-- anything that could keep me up for a few days and knock me out for a few hours. INT. MOLLY’S BEDROOM - EARLY MORNING The sun’s starting to come through the window and MOLLY, still in her clothes from the night before, is sitting on edge of the bed and staring into space.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: But I wasn’t just taking them to stay awake anymore. It was dark and friendless where I was. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 147.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I felt like I was in a hole so deep I could go fracking. It didn’t feel like depression, it felt more violent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HELLY smacks his hand on the table--

dialogues.speaker: HELLY
dialogues.text: (flipping his cards) Fuck you all! --and rakes in his chips.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I was tired of living in the frat house I’d built for degenerates. I was tired of the greed--mine, not theirs. Everybody's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once again it’s early morning and MOLLY’s still dressed f the night before. She’s standing by the window and holdin the curtain cord.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I was sick of being high all the time, I was sick of only living in the dark. MOLLY lets go of the curtain cord and a blackout curtain drops.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I couldn’t recognize myself and what I recognized I couldn’t stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A game has ended. MOLLY’s reconciling the books and DOUGL DOWNEY is pouring himself a drink.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: After a game one night Douglas Downey surprised me with a confession after opening with another detective story title. DOWNEY sits down next to Molly, takes a drink, and says--  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 148.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNEY
dialogues.text: Gut shot on the river. MOLLY closes her eyes for a second to brace herself again the incoherent conversation she knows is coming.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I want to say something.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNEY
dialogues.text: I want to say something.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (beat) Okay.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNEY
dialogues.text: I’m just gonna say it.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Cool.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNEY
dialogues.text: ‘Cause there’s a poem--a famous--a poem about thoughts left unexpressed. Two roads emerged from the woods. Do they explode? I don’t know. You like poetry?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I did until a second ago. I’m gonna call you a car and--

dialogues.speaker: DOWNEY
dialogues.text: I’m in love with you. MOLLY takes a moment before she says--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: This isn’t happening.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNEY
dialogues.text: You’re the woman I’ve always dreamed of and I’ve been dreaming--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Shhhstop it. Listen to me. Doug? I’m the woman all of you have always dreamed of. I'm the anti- wife. Instead of making you feel bad about going out every night and gambling, I encourage it. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 149.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And instead of asking you to cut down on your drinking, I have drinks served to you by models who simultaneously create the impression that you’re the kind of guy who can score a dime piece anytime you want. Do you know who Circe was? He HK

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Circe.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: (beat--confused and drunk) Used to play in Eddie Ting’s game?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Nope, Circe did not play in Eddie's game. She was the Greek goddess of magic and she gave men feasts with wine and honey and then she turned them into swine.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNEY
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Fantastic question. *

dialogues.speaker: DOWNEY
dialogues.text: Well I would never do that to you.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Missed the point by miles but that’s okay. And thanks for the * compliment.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNEY
dialogues.text: It wasn’t just an empty-- MOLLY’s packed up her laptop and thrown a few bound stack hundreds into a leather envelope which she’s zipped up an put in her bag.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Winston and Shelby are gonna close up and I'll see you next week. She heads for the door and we --

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 150.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The city is just waking up. MOLLY comes out of the hotel in a coat and with her bag o her shoulder. A driver gets out of a black SUV that’s wai on the corner and begins calling to Molly as he hustles o to her--

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER, (PAT)
dialogues.text: (calling) Hey! No! We’ve gone over this! You wait for me!

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: Someone knows about the game, knows you're carrying cash--right there is where they wait and right there is where they grab your bag. I can’t run him down in the car ‘cause Fifth Avenue’s one-way.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Sorry. PAT opens the door and MOLLY gets in the car. Her head is somewhere else as she looks out the window. PAT gets in the front and they pull out. They drive along in silence for a while, MOLLY looking ou the window as the almost-empty city goes by in the grey/b light of early morning.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I used to be a competitive athlete. I didn’t know if you knew that.

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: What sport?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Skiing. Freestyle.

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: Were you good?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (pause) I don’t know. The drive continues--  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 151.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I used Pat for security when I was going home with cash. He asked me if I could do him a favor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOLLY, dressed in a business outfit, is sitting at a tabl drinking iced tea and working on her laptop.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: He said there were a couple of hedge fund guys in New Jersey who wanted to play and he could score points with them if he was able to get them a meeting with me. I said sure and set the meeting for 5pm on a Thursday at the Four Seasons bar, knowing that if they were legit they'd recognize someone in the crowd at Happy Hour at the Four Seasons right after the closing bell. MOLLY spots two men enter the hotel bar. One of them is wearing a shiny brown suit with a t-shirt and a bullet on chain. The other is wearing a black shirt and black jeans

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It turns out I didn’t need to be that clever. These weren’t finance guys, they were from the cast of Jersey Boys. They stood at the entrance to the bar self- consciously--they were out of their element and tough guys try to look tougher when they’re insecure. MOLLY stands up and gives them a small wave and they make their way over to the table.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I had a good hunch what they wanted and I was gonna have to shut down this meeting quickly but without being rude to Joey Bag-a-Donuts and Secaucus Sal.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (shaking hands) I’m Molly Bloom, nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN G
dialogues.text: I’m John G.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 152.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (to the other) And you are?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (not interested in giving his name) Ah. MOLLY motions subtley to a waiter--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Can I get you guys a drink?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I don’t remember what the big guy ordered but I'll never forget what John G had. He looked at the waiter as if to say that he could handle himself among the Manhattan elite and said--

dialogues.speaker: JOHN G
dialogues.text: I'll have an Appletini.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (beat) Okay, alright.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN G
dialogues.text: So...How was your week?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: My week? It was fine, thank you. Pat said you might be interested in a game.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN G
dialogues.text: Pat’s a good guy, you like Pat?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Do I like--yes. He’s been my driver for almost two years.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN G
dialogues.text: Driver and security.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN G
dialogues.text: We hear a lot of good things about your game.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 153.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN G
dialogues.text: Who’s backing you?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (beat) Nobody.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN G
dialogues.text: Nobody.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN G
dialogues.text: Not Gigi?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I don’t know who that is.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN G
dialogues.text: You're solo.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN G
dialogues.text: Just Pat your driver.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Mm-hm.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN G
dialogues.text: That must be hard.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: It’s fine.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN G
dialogues.text: We want to partner with you. We’ve talked to Irv, Will--

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Eddie Ting.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN G
dialogues.text: --Eddie Ting, we’re gonna work with them too. We can make your life easier. (quieter) Nobody’1l fuck with you, nobody’1l stiff you.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) There’s a long silence before...

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (pause) I appreciate your offer but I’m really fine. I don’t carry a big debt sheet, I feel safe--

dialogues.speaker: JOHN G
dialogues.text: Ahh. You lied just then. (beat) When you said you don’t carry a big debt sheet. You’ve got two 2.8- million on the street right now, right as we’re sitting here, we do our research. That money should be in your hands ‘cause you owe it to people MOLLY looks at the two of them for a moment...

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Fellas, I'm sorry, it’s just a friendly game with higher stakes. It’s nice to meet you though. Let me know if there’s ever anything I can do for you, I like to do favors. They’ll put your drinks on my card. MOLLY gets up and heads out and suddenly we --

dialogues.speaker: SNAP TO BLACK
dialogues.text: We sit in silence for a moment before...

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: There are some gaps in my memory, which they say is common when you've had what they call an event. For instance I don’t remember where I was coming from and I don’t remember walking into my building. Just that my doorman, Reggie, said he had packages for me.
It's decorated for Christmas as MOLLY walks in from outsi and heads to the elevators.

dialogues.speaker: OF
dialogues.text: ee OK  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 155.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Ms. Bloom, I think I’ve got some things for you in the package room, I'll bring them on up.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Thanks, Reg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOLLY’s running a bath for herself.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: It was a night off and my plan was to take a bath and to try not to take drugs. The DOORBELL rings--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Reggie came up with my packages. MOLLY unlocks the front door and begins to open it. As so as she does the door flies open and a STRANGER--a heavy s man in his 50’s--pushes MOLLY back into the apartment and slams the door shut behind him and locks it.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, you’re in the wrong-- Wait, just hang on-- The STRANGER grabs MOLLY by the throat and slams her head against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: STRANGER
dialogues.text: Shut the fuck up. You need to shut your fuckin’ mouth right now, you follow me? He flings her head against the other wall and SLAMS HER I

dialogues.speaker: IT HARD--
dialogues.text: STRANGER (CONT’D) Do you get me?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (barely a rasp) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: STRANGER
dialogues.text: Open your mouth. MOLLY’s frozen. The STRANGER slaps her hard across the fa  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 156.

dialogues.speaker: STRANGER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Open your mouth. MOLLY opens her mouth a little and the STRANGER takes out gun and puts it between her teeth. STRANGER (CONT’D) You’re gonna keep quiet now. MOLLY’s teeth are chattering against the gun. STRANGER (CONT’D) Nod that you understand. MOLLY nods slightly. The STRANGER takes the gun out of he mouth and puts it to her head. STRANGER (CONT’D) Walk to the bedroom. The STRANGER walks her down the hall toward the bedroom. STRANGER (CONT’D) They say you got a smart mouth. What else can that mouth do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The STRANGER throws MOLLY down on the bed and MOLLY turns over so she’s sitting up by the headboard.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I have a lot of money, it’s all cash.

dialogues.speaker: STRANGER
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: In the safe. The STRANGER grabs MOLLY by the hair--

dialogues.speaker: STRANGER
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: In the closet. Right here. He drags MOLLY by the hair to the safe and pushes her to knees and gestures toward the safe with the gun. MOLLY taps her code into the keypad and the door swings o revealing rubber-banded stacks of hundreds and some jewel boxes as well as documents.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 157.

dialogues.speaker: STRANGER
dialogues.text: Give me the cash and the jewelry. Put it in a bag. MOLLY grabs one of her designer bags and puts the cash an jewelry inside.

dialogues.speaker: STRANGER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay. The stranger stoops down to MOLLY and grabs her face, sho it up against his. STRANGER (CONT’D) You don’t call the shots, you little cunt. This is your fault. He pulls her to her feet by her hair. STRANGER (CONT’D) If you weren’t such a bitch to my friends, I wouldn’t have to do this * now. * He slams MOLLY’s head into the wall. It knocks her semi- conscious. Then he punches her in the face. He punches he the face again. Her face is covered with blood as she backs away as far a she can into the closet. She’s having a hard time breathi as she chokes on her own blood. He punches her again. The grabs her and pulls her to her feet and out of the closet He takes his gun out of his jacket.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Please don’t. I have a family. *

dialogues.speaker: STRANGER
dialogues.text: Yeah. Your mom lives alone in * Keystone, Colorado. (beat) Right? (beat) Right, Molly? MOLLY shakes her head “no”-- *

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: No, my mother-- *

dialogues.speaker: STRANGER
dialogues.text: Yeah she does. * He smacks her bloody face as hard as he can.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 158. STRANGER (CONT’D) Open your eyes. Open your eyes, Molly. She’s barely conscious but she opens her eyes... STRANGER (CONT’D) It wasn’t an offer they made. It wasn’t a suggestion. This’ll be your only reminder. The last punch knocks her unconscious. She lies there as HEAR the stranger’s footsteps walk away off-screen, then door opening and closing. We move through a SERIES OF DISSOLVES-- --MOLLY still unconscious on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So that happened. --MOLLY pulling herself up to lock the deadbolt on the fr door and then sliding back down to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I couldn’t call a doctor or go to an E.R. They’d take one look at me and call the police. --Blood and water swirling down a shower drain.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My eyes were swollen and black, my lips were cut and bloody-- --MOLLY holds a folded, wet towel to her face, then lifts face off the towel and looks in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: --there was dried blood caked all over my neck and chest and I couldn’t feel my face. It was Christmas Eve. --MOLLY sits alone, staring into space in her darkened apartment, lit only by the city lights out the window.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Pat had set up the meeting. And he was how they knew where I lived. --MOLLY closes the blackout curtains in her bedroom again the daylight and then picks up a bag of ice and holds it against her face.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 159.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I stayed in my apartment for two weeks waiting for my face to heal and waiting for the phone call I knew was coming. --MOLLY checks her phone.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: But the call didn’t come. Where was the call from Joey Bag-a-Donuts saying-- --She checks her phone again.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: --"So maybe you’ve had a change of heart?” --MOLLY opens her front door and there’s a stack of uncollected newspapers there.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: After 10 days I opened my front door for the first time. People were coming back into town after-- --She’s going through the newspapers, throwing out the ol ones after she scans the front page.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: --New Year’s in Cabo and St. Bart’s and South Beach. My phone was blowing up with “When’s the next game?” But nothing from John G. MOLLY discards a newspaper...and then looks at it again.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And then right there on the front page of the The New York Times from 8 days ago--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: “Nearly 125 are Arrested in Sweeping FBI Mob Roundup.” Those guys were either laying low or they were in custody. Sometimes God happens fast.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 160.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOLLY’s face is almost healed and she’s applying make-up cover a dark spot under her eye.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: My face had healed enough so that a little make-up would cover the bruises that were left. I put together a week of games.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She’s getting dressed in one of her killer outfits.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: One week of games to get the 2.8- million I’d loaned out in credit and then I was out, I was done. One week of epic games. I had some of my London players in town and the Russians had visiting friends from Moscow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She’s putting on the finishing touches.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Jesse and Shelby had already started the game at the Plaza and were reporting heavy early action. I was on my way when my phone rang. It was Douglas Downey. MOLLY answers her phone--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (into phone) I’m on my way, Doug.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS, (ON THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: Wait! Molly, wait. I’m hiding in the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS, (ON THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: I need you to believe me--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Slow down.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 161.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS, (ON THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: I need you to believe me, okay? I’m hiding in the bathroom right now.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Who's bathroom?

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: At the suite. At the Plaza.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Why are you hiding in the bathroom?

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS, (ON THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: I would never tell them anything about--I said, “Guys, you want me to go further, you want me to go other places, I'll do it. But nothing about Molly, she can’t be touched. Just the Russians.”

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Doug, you’re drunk and a little hard to understand so I’ll see you in a few minutes when I get there.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS, (ON THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: Securities fraud.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You’re speaking in book titles.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Do you have an attorney? Does your attorney understand that I would never help them build a case against you? I would never--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Hang on--

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS, (ON THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: --give them anything against you? commit perjury before I did that. (pause) Are you there? MOLLY’s starting to put this together--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: What did you mean when you said “securities fraud”?

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS, (ON THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: It was such bullshit, it was 2006.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ee HK  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 162.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Were you arrested for securities fraud?

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS, (ON THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: It was bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Doug--

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS, (ON THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: I told them I’1l go further, I’11l go other places but not you. I love you whether you--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Doug! Listen to me! I need you to pull it together for a second. MOLLY’s other phone starts BUZZING and she glances at it-

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS, (ON THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: I love you whether you believe me or not.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Are you informing for the FBI?

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS, (ON THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: Should I have told you? That’s a question that’ll, you know, that’1ll haunt me for my days. For my days, Molly, but--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You're an FBI informant?

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS, (ON THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: I told them anyone but Molly. Always know that I was trying to protect you. MOLLY’s grabbed her other phone and looks at the text fro Shelby-- “FBI is here!!! Stay away!!!” DOUGLAS (ON THE PHONE) (CONT’D) You're someone I want to know so bad. I mean really know. Do you ever think to yourself-- MOLLY tosses the phone down and bolts to her bedroom wher she grabs a weekend bag and starts throwing things into i  163.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Five blocks away the FBI had raided my game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOLLY’s quickly rummaging through a series of designer ba until she finds some hundreds. She grabs them, grabs her laptop and grabs her bag and heads out.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I fully expected the lobby to be filled with guys wearing windbreakers but it wasn’t. INT. MOLLY’S LOBBY - NIGHT MOLLY gets off the elevator and walks into the lobby.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Ms. Bloom. Haven’t seen you for a while.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: You need a cab?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I'll get it myself. Hey Reg. I guess you never made it upstairs with those packages. She stuffs a hundred dollar bill in his jacket--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maybe I didn’t tip you enough before Christmas. MOLLY heads out onto--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where she flags down a cab.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I'd gone online and bought a plane ticket out of Newark Airport. She gets in the cab--  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 164.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: JFK please. She opens her laptop and begins tapping keys--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I logged into my bank account where the balance should have read a little more than 5-million dollars. MOLLY stares at something we can’t see. She’s expressionl Then we see the screen--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: It said I had negative 9-million, nine-hundred and ninety-nine thousand, nine-hundred and ninety- nine dollars and ninety-nine cents along with a note to contact the U.S. Attorney’s Office. My bank assets had been seized.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOLLY and CHARLIE are sitting across a table from HARRISO WELLSTONE and BRENNAN, two prosecutors in their 30’s.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: And she flew to Denver.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: She flew to Denver where her mother picked her up and drove them both to her mother’s home in Keystone. That was two years ago. It’s been two years since Ms. Bloom ran a game. I want to mention as well that two days after arriving in Keystone she voluntarily checked herself into a 28-day rehab and has been clean and sober for two years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOLLY, in jeans, a t-shirt, and a baseball cap, is waitin line at the checkout along with a half-dozen others--all women.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 165.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: My third week at rehab they took us on a field trip to a grocery store because most addicts have to be reintroduced to simple things like making your bed and buying eggs. One of the women further up in the line sees something on magazine rack and pulls it off. She begins excitedly talk to the others next to her and flipping through the pages.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: At the check-out line I saw one of my roommates pull a magazine off the rack. She started looking at me and back at the magazine and back at me. Then she showed me the cover and said, “Is this you?!” It was me, along with four of the players from the Hollywood game, including Player X and Player Y.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOLLY sits on the curb reading the magazine.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: They’d gotten a hold of someone's deposition from the Brad Marion bankruptcy suit. The game was run by a cocktail waitress turned poker princess who, they said, provided the players with drugs and prostitutes. A blind quote referred to Donnie Silverman, who they mis- referenced as a winner of the World Poker Championship. I can’t be a hundred percent sure that Louis Butterman gave my deposition to the tabloids, but I’m a hundred percent sure Louis Butterman gave my deposition to the tabloids.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: And during the two years she lived with her mother in Keystone she wrote the book you have there.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 166.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: Were the women who worked for you call girls?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: No sir.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: They never exchanged sex for money?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: No

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: Have you ever exchanged sex for money?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I think he was talking to me.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I meant no, she’s not answering that question. The purpose of this meeting-—-

dialogues.speaker: HARRISON
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: The purpose of the meeting--

dialogues.speaker: HARRISON
dialogues.text: We're off the record.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No we’re not.

dialogues.speaker: HARRISON
dialogues.text: Do you see a stenographer in here?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yes, we are off the record inasmuch as there’s no record but you’re free to act on information that you’re given and we’re not giving it to you for free. I’ve been sitting at this table for five hours, waiting for the opportunity to implore you to do the right thing while begging my client for the last three weeks to act in her own best interest. And neither of those things should be hard. (pause) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The purpose of this meeting is for you to meet Molly Bloom and discover, as I have, that she’s not the person the press has invented.

dialogues.speaker: HARRISON
dialogues.text: She’s not under federal indictment for getting bad press, Charlie. And the purpose of the meeting, for me, is to discover if your client is willing to cooperate with the government in putting away some bad people.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: HARRISON
dialogues.text: You’re not willing to cooperate?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: No, I’ve never traded sex for money. (beat) I’m still not sure if there’s a record but if there is I wanted to make sure that was in it.

dialogues.speaker: HARRISON
dialogues.text: It appears to me that throughout your career as a gamerunner you were extremely diligent about vetting the players.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I was.

dialogues.speaker: HARRISON
dialogues.text: But you let four guys play in the game without knowing they were connected?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Plus an FBI informant, it’s pretty embarrassing. They’re still waiting for an answer.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (beat) I was high at the end and doing my job badly. I'll also add that in my limited experience with the Russian mob, they don’t give many clues that they’re mobsters. In my experience with the Italian mob on the other hand--  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 168.

dialogues.speaker: HARRISON
dialogues.text: Help us.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I don’t know anything that can help you.

dialogues.speaker: HARRISON
dialogues.text: Yes--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: If I did--

dialogues.speaker: HARRISON
dialogues.text: Yes you do. You can provide color. (beat) You can paint a picture. You can tell us that Druzhinsky wore a Rolex and drove a Phantom. You can tell us that Illya Gershen showed up with a quarter-million dollars cash in a backpack and you can tell us how much action Helly was taking on a sports bet. MOLLY’s starting to get dizzy from this but she’s fightin through it.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (pause) Uh...No one was allowed to place sports bets from the room, they had to go outside--I’d have no idea how much anyone was taking or laying.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: So now you’re saying you knew they were making and taking sports bets?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: No sir, that was the point of them leaving the room. They could’ve been calling their mothers for all I knew.

dialogues.speaker: HARRISON
dialogues.text: Molly?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: HARRISON
dialogues.text: I don’t believe you. In Mike Druzhinsky’s phone intercepts alone- -just Druzhinsky--your name comes up nineteen times. “ (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 169.

dialogues.speaker: HARRISON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We need Molly,” “Get Molly,” “Bring Molly”--it strongly suggests that you were important to his business and so it’s hard to believe that someone with your savvy and obvious intellect--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: They’re talking about the drug. (beat) “Get molly”, “Bring molly”, “We need molly”, they’re talking about the drug, ecstacy. There’s a long silence in the room...and then CHARLIE can help laughing--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Shit. My office was next to yours for two years and I saw you make some bone-headed moves but I’ve never seen any prosecutor step in it the way you just did. You should thank all of the gods that there’s no physical record of that exchange.

dialogues.speaker: HARRISON
dialogues.text: Look--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No you look, Harry--

dialogues.speaker: HARRISON
dialogues.text: You gonna implore me to do the right thing?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (shouting) You caught a dolphin in a tuna net and you know it! The rage that’s been building up in CHARLIE for hours if weeks--maybe years--has finally exploded.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (beat) Molly Bloom does not belong ina RICO indictment, are you outta your minds?! She does not belong in a mob indictment, she raked a game, that’s it, for seven months two years ago. Why? Because she was giving credit in the millions and she didn’t want to use muscle to collect. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy)

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (pause) She’s had opportunity after opportunity to greatly benefit herself by simply telling the real stories she knows. I have the forensic imaging going back to 2007- -text messages, emails--movie stars, rock stars and billionaires who were explicit--some of them married with kids--but that’s the tip of the iceberg. A guy comes this close to being named U.S. Ambassador to Monaco, he’s withdrawn from consideration at the last minute and nobody knows why. She does. CEOs with college-age mistresses, an SVP of an investment bank who wanted her to help him put a marked deck in the game, the head of a movie studio who texted her that a particular star was too black for his taste, J. Edgar Hoover didn’t have this much shit on Bobby! (beat) She could’ve written a best seller, she could have been set for life, she’s got the winning lottery ticket and she won’t cash it. She settled the Brad Marion suit for a half a million dollars just so she wouldn’t have to testify and that was only the first time you guys cleaned her out. Your office took every dollar she had ina Constitutionally fucked up seizure and then you put the IRS on her to tax the money you seized? I’ve been in those strategy meetings. You broke her back so she couldn’t possibly afford to defend herself. And now she has an opportunity to guarantee her own freedom by just...“providing some color”...and she still won’t do it. This woman doesn’t belong in a RICO indictment, she belongs in Congress. She belongs in the pulpit of a synagogue, she belongs on a box of Wheaties. So yes I am, I’m imploring you to do the right thing. She knows nothing about the three Mikes. She knows nothing about Taiwanchik or the TGO or insurance fraud. (MORE )
He OK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HO eH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 171.
