dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Between the two of us we’ve appeared in front of this judge 28 times as prosecutors and not once has he deviated from our sentencing recommendations, he’s not gonna start now. I know you’ve been putting this bust together for three years and there’s no one who doesn’t want to see mobsters in jail, including and especially the only person in this room who’s had one of them put a gun in her mouth. Probation. Community service. Or better yet, consider that all she did was run a poker game exactly the same way every casino in America does and drop the goddamn charges. There’s silence after that long speech. Then HARRISON to turns to MOLLY--

dialogues.speaker: HARRISON
dialogues.text: Do you have anything you’d like to add?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (pause) I am guilty.

dialogues.speaker: HARRISON
dialogues.text: (pause) Yeah. (beat) Molly, I'd like to talk to your lawyer in private if that’s alright with you. MOLLY turns to Charlie and CHARLIE nods that it’s okay.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Can you get some dinner for an hour and then meet me back at the office?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The city’s decked out for Christmas. MOLLY’s standing in front of a hot dog cart across the street from the Plaza Hotel and staring up at her old stomping ground. She turn suddenly to the hot dog vendor.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 172.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Hm? I’m sorry?

dialogues.speaker: HOT DOG VENDOR
dialogues.text: Did you want a hot dog?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (beat) Uh...a pretzel please. MOLLY takes two singles out of her wallet and trades them the pretzels.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: HOT DOG VENDOR
dialogues.text: Merry Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: To you too. MOLLY walks up the sidewalk a little bit--the street is l with carriages and horses. MOLLY stops at the first carri and asks the driver-- MOLLY (CONT’D) Is it okay if I feed your horse? The driver nods, “Sure go ahead.” MOLLY takes a piece of her pretzel, offers it in her flattened hand and the horse takes it.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (whispering) On my signal, the revolution will begin, and I will lead us all to freedom. MOLLY rips her pretzel into a few pieces and drops them i the horse’s feed bucket. She shoves her hands in her coat pockets and moves on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOLLY’s walking down a path and the skating rink comes in view. It’s lit up and the skaters are making their way ar the rink with Christmas music coming from the speakers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOLLY steps up to the window which is being manned by a woman.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 173.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Hi, I’d like to rent a pair of skates, size 6, but I just spent my last two dollars on dinner which I ended up feeding to a horse. These are 800-dollar leather Chanel gloves and I’1ll trade you.

dialogues.speaker: SKATE RENTAL WOMAN
dialogues.text: 800 dollar gloves?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yes. And they keep your hands just as warm as the 10-dollar kind.

dialogues.speaker: SKATE RENTAL WOMAN
dialogues.text: Are you alright?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Mm-hm. I’m divesting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOLLY’s finishing lacing her skates on a bench, takes off coat and steps out onto the rink. As soon as she begins skating it’s clear that she knows how to skate. And as sh starts skating faster it’s clear that if she hadn’t chose skiing she could’ve had a future in speed skating. She begins to skate faster and faster--weaving through th other skaters with impressive grace and athleticism. And speed. More and more and more speed as she begins her sec lap. Faster. Effortless speed. Two RINK EMPLOYEES on skates and in orange vests see her one of them shouts out--

dialogues.speaker: RINK EMPLOYEE
dialogues.text: (shouting)

dialogues.speaker: HEY
dialogues.text: MOLLY pays no attention as she flies through the other skaters. RINK EMPLOYEE (CONT’D)

dialogues.speaker: HEY MISS
dialogues.text: The two rink employees set out chasing after her on their skates.

dialogues.speaker: LADY
dialogues.text: MOLLY flips around, skating backwards now, just as fast a she was before.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 174.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (calling back) Catch me! (louder) Come on! Catch me! MOLLY flips forward again and rockets away. As she passes group of observers watching from the railing she hears a man’s voice off-screen.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Bend your knees. MOLLY turns around to see who just said that-- * --it was her FATHER. MOLLY crashes into the railing and f down, creating a chain reaction pile-up of skaters who fa over her and then over each other.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (to the other skaters) Sorry. Sorry. The two RINK EMPLOYEES skate up and grab MOLLY by each ar

dialogues.speaker: RINK EMPLOYEE
dialogues.text: We're taking you off the ice right now, miss, and if you give us any trouble we’re calling the police. As the RINK EMPLOYEES continue to skate MOLLY off the ice like a prisoner, her father asks simply--

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: How’s it goin’?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOLLY’s father puts her coat over her as she sits on the bench.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: What are you doing in New York and how did you know I was at the skating rink? ee OK

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: I’m both your father and a doctor of the mind. I’m in New York because that’s where you are and I called your mom at the hotel and she said you were here. Listen, it’s not a big deal but from what I saw out there I think you’re having a small breakdown.

dialogues.speaker: HH HK
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 175.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: That’s weird, I can’t think of why.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: I would think it was because of the arrest and not knowing what’s going to happen.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Old man, do you really not recognize sarcasm?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Do you? Drink this. He’s handed her a styrofoam cup.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I can’t drink, I’m an alcoholic but thanks for remembering.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: It’s hot chocolate.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: And for diagnostic purposes, do you think we’re in a cocktail lounge right now? ‘Cause if you do I have to walk you into Bellevue tonight. Did you know I can do that? I can institutionalize people, it’s fantastic. I want to check your pulse. He takes her wrist and looks at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (pause) Dad--

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Hang on.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (pause) Have you found a pulse?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Yeah, I just like looking at this watch. eH OF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: eK  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 176.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Dad, I can see you're getting warmed up but I don’t have the emotional bandwidth to defend my “as usual irresponsible behavior.”

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: I know, I got your e-mail. I get that I’m not welcome in your life right now as your father though you should know I could give a shit if I’m welcome or not. But I’m not here in my capacity as your father. I’m indifferent to whether your father lives or dies. I'm a very expensive therapist and I’m here to give you one free session.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You think what I need right now is a therapist?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: (almost laughing) Yuh-huh!

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I have to be back at my lawyer’s office soon.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: You like your lawyer?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I wasn’t asking for money when I called you, dad, I just needed my dad. And God forbid you part with a nickel.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Yeah Tiny Tim, you grew up on a lake and you've skied all over the world, were those work houses tough?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (getting up) I have to go.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Molly--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I have to go.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 177.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Molly, sit the fuck down! MOLLY does as she’s told. There’s a long silence before..

dialogues.speaker: FATHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (pause) Alright. We’re gonna do three years of therapy in three minutes.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: I’m gonna do what patients have been begging therapists to do for a hundred years--I’m just gonna give you the answers.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: To what?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Well let’s start with this. Why does a young woman who, at 22, has a gold-plated resume--why does she run high-stakes poker games?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Why did I choose to make a lot of money, that’s a head scratcher.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: You were gonna be a success at anything you wanted and you know it. If you’d gone to law school you'd have been a partner by now. Why this?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (beat) I don’t know. Drugs. Her father waves that off--

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: You didn’t start with drugs until the end. They weren’t the problem, they were the medicine. No. It was so you could control powerful men. Your addiction was having power over powerful men.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: That’s really what you think?  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 178.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: No, I know it for sure. You’ve now completed your first year of therapy.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I saw an opportunity, it wasn’t about you.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: It wasn’t just about me.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: It wasn’t at all about you.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: It was. Second year, second question.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Do you think you were a good husband?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: What do you care?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I care because you were married to my mother! I care because my father’s an asshole!

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Congratulations, you’ve completed Year Two. For the record, your father raised three kids on a college professor’s salary. One of them is a two-time Olympian, sixth- round draft pick of the Philadelphia Eagles and a leading philanthropist. Another is a cardiothoracic surgeon at Mass General and the third built a multi- million dollar business using not much more than her wits.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I’m about to plead guilty ina federal court.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Nobody’s perfect. The point is I must have done a few things right. Last question.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I have to go.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Last question, Mol. I’1l answer it but you have to ask it.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you like me as much as my brothers?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: There it is. I did. It only from time to time appeared that I didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (pause) It only appeared that you didn’t?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: That’s some Category-5 bullshit, dad. Why would--It only appeared-- Why would--Okay, I had an attitude. I talked back. And I broke some normal adolescent rules. I snuck phone time past curfew, I took your car when I wasn’t allowed to--

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: --and drove it into a McDonald's.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: And kids get punished for that but they don’t get--you’d turn into another person--your voice, your face, it was--

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: --because I knew you knew.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (pause) You knew I knew what?

dialogues.speaker: CAMCORDER
dialogues.text: The birthday interview we saw at the beginning--  180.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What do you think about the following concepts? I’m just gonna run them by you. Marriage.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: That I was cheating. I knew you knew.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Family.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I didn’t know that until I was 20. He shakes his head “No”...

dialogues.speaker: YEAR OLD GIRL
dialogues.text: I don’t trust people.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: You'd known since you were five. You saw me in my car. And you didn’t really know what you saw.

dialogues.speaker: YEAR OLD GIRL
dialogues.text: I don’t have heroes.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: (beat) You knew, honey, and I knew you knew. And that’s how I reacted to the shame. And you reacted by showing seething contempt for me, by driving my car into a McDonald’s--  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 181.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: --and wanting to have power over powerful men?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: No, that was a red herring just to make you mad.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You’re such an asshole, dad--

dialogues.speaker: YOU TRIPPED OVER A STICK
dialogues.text: (beat)

dialogues.speaker: OKAY
dialogues.text: (pause) Ten years ago you tripped over a stick. It was a one-in-a-million thing. You tripped over a stick. That’s what you did wrong. (pause) There’s your session. It’s funny how much faster you can do it when you’re not charging by the hour. I’m your father. Trying to comprehend how much I love you would be like trying to visualize the size of the universe. (pause) I didn’t know you’d gotten beaten up until I read it in your book, it was a helluva way to learn about it. You should know I’m hiring someone to find the guy who did it and then I’m hiring someone to kill him.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (smiles) Don’t even joke about that, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: I’m not.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: It wasn’t a purse snatcher, it was the mafia.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: I don’t care if it was the leader of Hamas-- (beat) --Someone put their hands on you...they’re gonna suffer. MOLLY looks and sees to her surprise that her father is She holds him--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ee ee ee:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 182.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: It’s okay, dad. It’s alright-- Her father is holding her tight--

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: They’re gonna suffer.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I’m fine. Really, dad, I’m fine.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: They’re gonna suffer. They keep holding each other tight as the skaters skate i the background. INT. CHARLIE’S OFFICE - NIGHT CHARLIE’s alone in his office with the city flickering ou the window. He’s holding a deck of cards and after a mome deals himself two down. He looks at them, then he burns a card and deals himself the flop. He tosses his hole cards the middle and folds. MOLLY comes and stands in the doorway for a moment...

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Did you know that the center of our galaxy smells like rum and raspberries? It’s true. At the center of the galaxy is ethyl formate, which is the same gas that gives rum its smell and raspberries their taste.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Why do you know these things?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: To stay busy during games I surfed the internet. Then I started taking online courses. I’m 12 credits away from a degree in astronomy, I didn’t even know I was enrolled. (pause) I want to thank you for what you said tonight.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Molly, there’s a new offer on the table.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: What is it?  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 183.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: We hand over our forensic imaging.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (pause) I don’t get it.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: We give them the forensic imaging of your texts and e-mails and in exchange--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: In exchange--What could they possibly offer me to do that?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Your money back. (pause) They’1l return all of your money. MOLLY takes in that information...doesn’t know whether to laugh or cry and just says...

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (pause) Yeah, that sounds about right. CHARLIE laughs a little.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is that why they took the money in the first place? So they could offer it back to me?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I think they just wanted to buy an espresso machine.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: A four and a half million dollar espresso machine?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Hey, for what it’s worth, if we were going to trial we’d have to hand over the forensic imaging in discovery.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yes but that’s different from voluntarily handing it over.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Sure. (pause) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 184.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But it’s not really voluntary anymore when the alternative is prison. Which is what they’re gonna recommend--three years.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (beat) Why do you keep breaking eye contact with me?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I’m looking right at you.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You think I should do it.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You have to let me keep you out of prison.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You've seen what’s on those hard drives.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: A lot more than a little color.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I don’t care.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Careers will be ruined. Families. Wives, lives on both coasts--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Listen to me. When a rich guy goes to jail he spreads money around. His lawyer knows how to take care of it. He spreads money around and you don’t have any. The composition of female inmates in federal prison- -they did not commit financial crimes. They’re drug dealers and they get raped by prison guards and you will not be anonymous, Molly, you'll be a target.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Children will read their father’s text messages saying he wished he’d never had kids. These guys--  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy)

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Where are they?! (beat) Why are you in this alone? Where are your friends? Where’s one guy saying, “Molly, I know you’re doing everything you can to save my life, the least I can do is take care of your legal bills.”

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: If this is about paying your fee--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It’s not! I’ll pay my fee, okay?!

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You’re gonna pay yourself two- hundred and--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: My firm, it’s my firm that gets-- where are they, Molly? You kept their secrets. Where are these people you’re protecting by not telling the whole story in the book, by settling the Brad Marion suit, by turning down four and a half million dollars of your own money and by going to jail? Where’d everybody go?!

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: It’s not their names I’m protecting, Charlie, it’s mine.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Your integrity?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Frame it anyway you want but it’s still throwing other people under the bus.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: And you know I admire that but we have to live in the real world now. I’m sufficiently convinced that he’s gonna recommend jail time as a coercive measure so you don’t have the luxury of integrity.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I never thought I'd hear you say that. 185.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy)

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I’m saying it, that should mean something to you. I’m saying it. We’re taking the deal.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You stay out of jail and you have your money back to pay your debts and start a new life. (pause) If this is a self-imposed punishment for naming the four guys in the book--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: It’s not.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I think it is.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I noticed you kept that out of your speech to the prosecutors but it’s not.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I think your psychotic need for redemption is making you make bad-- They were already in the tabloids ‘cause of Brad Marion!

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: It doesn’t have anything to do with that!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Then take the deal!

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (calmly) ‘Kay Listen to me. I’m named after my great-grandmother.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I don’t care.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Molly Dubin Bloom--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: We will stay here all night until-- 186.  They stare Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy)

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: --is my name.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: --you understand that no one gives a shit about your good name.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I do!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Because--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Because it’s--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Tell me why.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (shouting) BECAUSE IT’S ALL I HAVE LEFT! BECAUSE IT’S MY NAME! (deliberately--knowingly) “And I‘ll never have another.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: at each other...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (pause) You read The Crucible?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (pause) Yeah, everyone’s right, it’s great. (beat) I want to go into court and plead guilty. No deals, no trades...I want to plead guilty for the crime I’m guilty of.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (pause) I am...so sorry that I wasn’t able to-- 187.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 188.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: This was all me. Listen up a second okay? For most of my life, for whatever reason, I’ve experienced men as nocturnal predators. Degenerate gluttons of sloth. Crass and stupid misogynists who measure their worth in worthless ways.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: And then you met me?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (pause) No, Counselor Ego. I’ve known good men--beginning with my father and my brothers.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I know, I was just-- She puts her hand on his shoulder--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: But you confirmed it wasn’t a fluke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s a freezing cold day. Paparazzi and a couple of TMZ-t film crews are behind police sawhorses. MOLLY--along with MOTHER, FATHER and her two handsome brothers, JORDAN and JEREMY, step out of a black SUV where they’re met by CHAR STELLA, and a couple of UNIFORMED POLICE OFFICERS. They h up the courthouse steps as cameras come to life and some questions we can’t really make out are shouted and ignore Molly’s MOTHER takes her arm. MOLLY turns to her--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You alright?

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: (pause--not allowing herself to cry) New Yorkers think this is cold weather? In Colorado this is a beach day.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: There you are. (then to her FATHER) You alright?  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 189.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: These people taking pictures and shouting? The desire--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: --to punch them as hard as I can in the mouth--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: --is overwhelming.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yup. They head into the courthouse as we --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not too many people. It’s just another day’s business for court. The family takes its seats and STELLA takes a seat few rows down and on the aisle. HARRISON and BRENNAN are already at the prosecutor’s table discussing some things. MOLLY walks in with CHARLIE and they head down to the def table.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (TO CHARLIE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why isn’t Stella in school?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: She insisted. MOLLY turns and goes back up the aisle and kneels down wh STELLA’s sitting.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (pause) There’s gonna come a moment in your life that tests your character. When that moment comes, it’1l be better if you don’t have any. After a moment, STELLA smiles and then laughs a little. M gives her a light smack on the knee and joins Charlie at table.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 190.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: The business of the court began. We continue semi-MOS as Molly begins narrating over a ser of easy DISSOLVES--

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE
dialogues.text: MOLLY and

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: We stood for the Honorable Judge Dustin Foxman and counsel entered their names for the record.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: The docket was called and some pro forma instructions were given to counsel. CHARLIE stand up.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And I was asked a series of questions from a script the judge had in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE FOXMAN
dialogues.text: What is your full name?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Molly Dubin Bloom.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE FOXMAN
dialogues.text: How old are you? The questioning continues. JUDGE FOXMAN (CONT’D) Have you taken any drugs, medicine or pills or had any alcoholic beverages in the past 48 hours?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Sudafed.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE FOXMAN
dialogues.text: Is there anything about the reasons for your taking Sudafed that would interfere with what’s going on here today?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE FOXMAN
dialogues.text: I state for the record that I’ve also taken Sudafed in the last 48 hours.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: 87 questions he was required to ask before he’d permit me to plead guilty.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE FOXMAN
dialogues.text: Is your mind clear today, Ms. Bloom?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yes it is.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE FOXMAN
dialogues.text: Do you understand what is going on here today?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE FOXMAN
dialogues.text: Under the Constitution and laws of the United States you have a right to plead to the charges in the indictment, do you understand that?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yes Your Honor.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE FOXMAN
dialogues.text: And do you understand that?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE FOXMAN
dialogues.text: At that trial you would be presumed to be innocent and you would not have to prove that you were innocent, do you understand that?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yes Your Honor.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE FOXMAN
dialogues.text: If you plead guilty and I accept your plea, you will give up your right to appeal along with all the other rights I’ve enumerated, do you understand?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE FOXMAN
dialogues.text: Even now as you are entering this plea you have the right to change your mind and plead not guilty to Count Twenty of the indictment and go to trial, do you understand that?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE FOXMAN
dialogues.text: Do you understand that you are charged in Count Twenty with operating an illegal gambling business in violation of Title 18 United States Code Sections 1955 and 2?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yes, I understand.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE FOXMAN
dialogues.text: Understanding everything you've just been told, do you now wish to enter a plea?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yes sir.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 193.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE FOXMAN
dialogues.text: How do you plead to the charge?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Guilty, Your Honor.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE FOXMAN
dialogues.text: Your plea has been so recorded and you can take your seat. Before we move to the sentencing phase I'd like a word with counsel please. CHARLIE, HARRISON, and BRENNAN all stand up to approach t bench--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And then something happened.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE FOXMAN
dialogues.text: (to CHARLIE) Pardon me, Mr. Jaffey, just government counsel. CHARLIE’s a little confused, this is very unusual.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yes Judge. CHARLIE sits back down as HARRISON and BRENNAN have a pri conversation at the bench.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (beat) What’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. The wait continues...

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (pause) What is it usually?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (pause) I can’t feel my legs. I’ve never been this scared in my life. CHARLIE looks at her...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yes you have.  The JUDGE MOLLY and Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 194. tells the prosecutors they can step back.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE FOXMAN
dialogues.text: Would the defendant please rise for sentencing. CHARLIE stand.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE FOXMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Based on all available information, this court manifestly disagrees with the government’s sentencing recommendation. This courthouse is located three streets from the financial district, which is populated by men and women who will commit more serious crimes by lunchtime today than the defendant has committed in this indictment. I simply don’t see how either the People or the cause of justice are served by locking Molly Bloom in prison. We see the family’s reaction--holding their breath, as CHARLIE closes his eyes a moment and exhales in relief an anticipation. The JUDGE continues semi-MOS--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It was as casual as if he was ordering lunch off a menu.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE FOXMAN
dialogues.text: Ms. Bloom, this court sentences you to two-hundred hours of community service, one year of supervised probation and drug testing and a one-hundred thousand dollar fine. This case is adjourned. He raps his gavel. Everyone rushes a stunned Molly to congratulate her.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: And that was that. There was crying and hugging, jokes from my brothers--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --as MOLLY, CHARLIE, STELLA, and MOLLY’s FAMILY exit and down the stairs with CHARLIE casually waving off question  195.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: --tough talk about how no one messes with the Blooms and level- headed talk about Christmas miracles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The seven of them are having a lively dinner.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Steaks and beer bought by my father and full reenactments. In the middle of the revelry, we start to slowly PUSH IN MOLLY, whose face is beginning to change a little.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And in the middle of it all, as grateful as you are, the reality starts creeping toward you like the tide. And that’s the first time you have the thought...”What do I do now?”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s the slope we were on at the beginning, windy and forbidding. We’re watching from a few hundred feet away a we can barely see MOLLY on the ground where she’s just ha her accident. She’s surrounded by EMTs, ski patrol, her c and her father. From time to time we’ll see the other ski standing by silently, waiting and hoping. We can hear the two TV COMMENTATORS--one male, one female and a female REPORTER on the ground near the action.

dialogues.speaker: MALE COMMENTATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She’s been laying still for about a minute now. I want to emphasize again, our cameras can’t get in there so we don’t know if she’s conscious.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE COMMENTATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She fell hard and then kept going at a punishing speed.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I'm a felon. I’m 35 years old, unemployed, and pled guilty ina mob indictment.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 196.

dialogues.speaker: MALE COMMENTATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Molly Bloom is of course the sister of Jeremy Bloom who holds the world’s number one ranking. That’s her longtime coach there, Ted Keene, and her father.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I owe the government close to two- million dollars in taxes assessed on the civil forfeiture plus the hundred-thousand dollar fine. And they’re gonna come get it.

dialogues.speaker: MALE COMMENTATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: On the doorstep of making the Olympic team.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I have a quarter of a million dollars in legal bills.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE COMMENTATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She came back from an injury when she was just 13. Emergency back surgery. You know I wonder if Tracy’s got an update for us on the ground--Tracy?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I don’t know what I’d say in a job interview, or if I’ll ever be given a job interview. I won’t know how to explain this. And for some reason I’m never allowed to go to Canada.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Guys, we’re hearing the chopper blades down here.

dialogues.speaker: MALE COMMENTATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: That’s the sound you don’t want to hear.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE COMMENTATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: They don’t think--

dialogues.speaker: MALE COMMENTATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Yeah, they don’t think they can get her off this mountain.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And I’m not allowed to vote.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 197.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE COMMENTATOR, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: If she can hear those chopper blades--

dialogues.speaker: TRACY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She’s moving, guys!

dialogues.speaker: MALE COMMENTATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She’s moving.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She’s waving off the chopper. We see someone with the ski patrol get on their radio and look to the sky where the chopper is. MOLLY sits up even though the EMTs and her father and the coach are telling her to sit still.

dialogues.speaker: MALE COMMENTATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This is something.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I’ll tell you guys, as banged up as she has to be right now, she appears more angry with herself than she is hurt.

dialogues.speaker: MALE COMMENTATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We can see she’s being helped to her feet now. MOLLY takes a towel and wipes the remaining blood off her face.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Did anything good come of this? Not really. But I learned things. For instance the largest diamond ever found isn’t on Earth. It’s a burned out corpse of a star that’s 50 light years away in the Constellation Centaurus.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She’s on her feet.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: It weighs 5-million trillion trillion pounds which is 10-billion trillion trillion carats.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 198.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She’s looking back up the slope, trying to figure out what went wrong, I’m sure that question’s gonna haunt her.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: So I learned that our galaxy smells like rum and raspberries and has a floating diamond the size of Polaris. APPLAUSE from all the spectators and officials.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE COMMENTATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You have to wonder about the psychological toll. Coming that close after 18 years only to lose it like that.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And I learned that I’m very hard to kill.

dialogues.speaker: MALE COMMENTATOR, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: You and I both know people who’ve never gotten over it.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE COMMENTATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I don’t know if the young woman we've just seen is one of those people. We may not see her ski competitively again but I think we’re gonna see her. She’1ll be back. As the ski patrol starts to move MOLLY down off the slope the camera counters in the other direction--still at a distance--so that we’re turning to look at the crash site from a different angle. And as we continue the camera move, coming into the foreground of the shot... ...we see the PINE BOUGH.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE COMMENTATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She’ll be back.

dialogues.speaker: MALE COMMENTATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Alright, next up in the gate is Whitney Summerhill who’s currently sitting in 12th place after--
